questions.text: A 56-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband 30 minutes after a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. Over the past 3 months, she has had recurrent headaches and worsening early-morning vomiting. She has no personal or family history of a seizure disorder. An MRI of the brain shows a central mass; surgical resection is planned. One day before the surgery, the patient has another generalized seizure and, despite resuscitative efforts, she dies. Gross examination of the brain at autopsy is shown. Which of the following was the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oligodendrogliomas are slow-growing tumors that arise from oligodendrocytes. While these tumors can manifest with the nonspecific neurological symptoms seen here, the disease course of oligodendrogliomas is often much less rapid. Additionally, oligodendrogliomas are usually found in the frontal lobe, while this patient's tumor is located temporally. On gross pathological examination, oligodendrogliomas may show areas of necrosis, but hemorrhage and microvascular proliferation, which are seen here, are not characteristic.

B) INCORRECT:

Hemangioblastomas are benign, slow-growing, highly vascularized tumors. Unlike this patient's supratentorial tumor, hemangioblastomas are typically located in the cerebellum (infratentorial), which is why symptoms often include cerebellar defects (e.g., ataxia). Features of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., headaches, vomiting) may occur if the tumor compresses the fourth ventricle. On gross pathological examination, these tumors appear red due to their high vascularity and they are often located within a cyst.

C) CORRECT:

Glioblastomas are highly malignant, rapidly progressive brain tumors that commonly manifest with nonspecific neurological symptoms, as seen in this patient. In keeping with the autopsy findings here, glioblastomas are typically located in the white matter of the cerebral hemispheres (e.g., left temporal lobe), although they can cross the midline (butterfly glioma). Gross hemorrhage, central necrosis, and microvascular proliferation are further pathological characteristics. On MRI, the tumor would appear as a ring-enhancing mass due to central necrosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Schwannomas are benign tumors that arise from the Schwann cells of peripheral nerves. Unlike this patient's supratentorial tumor, Schwannomas are usually located in the cerebellopontine angle (infratentorial) because they primarily arise within the vestibular portion of the vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII). Symptoms depend on the nerves affected by the tumor (e.g., dizziness, hearing loss, facial nerve palsy); however, headaches, vomiting, and seizures would not be characteristic. On gross examination, schwannomas may be visible as calcifications, cystic components, necrosis, and hemorrhage.
Image Description:

Acoustic neuromas are benign tumors that arise from Schwann cells and primarily originate within the vestibular portion of cranial nerve VIII. The tumor originates within the internal acoustic canal with variable extension into the cerebellopontine angle. Early symptoms occur due to pressure on the cochlear nerve (unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus) and vestibular nerve (dizziness, unsteady gait, disequilibrium). If the tumor further expands into the cerebellopontine angle, further symptoms arise due to compression of CN V (paresthesia, hypoesthesia, unilateral facial pain), CN VII (unilateral facial weakness), and the cerebellum (ataxia).

E) INCORRECT:

Brain metastases of carcinomas (e.g., lung, melanoma, renal) are the most common type of intracranial tumors in adults. While metastases can also manifest with the nonspecific neurological symptoms seen here, additional features of a primary malignancy would be expected. Moreover, gross pathological examination of brain metastases usually reveals multiple, well-circumscribed lesions at the gray-white junction.

F) INCORRECT:

Meningiomas are benign, slow-growing tumors that arise from arachnoid cells. While these tumors can manifest with the nonspecific neurological symptoms seen here, they are usually asymptomatic and found incidentally on imaging. Meningiomas typically develop outside of the brain parenchyma, while this patient's tumor is within the temporal lobe. Gross pathological examination of meningiomas shows a round, encapsulated, grayish-white tumor with a firm to hard texture.
questions.hint: This patient presented with nonspecific neurological symptoms (seizures, headaches, early-morning vomiting), most likely caused by a tumor derived from astrocytes.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the physician for the evaluation of a 1-month history of episodes of irritability and occasional vomiting. The parents report that she has been drowsy during much of the day and has not engaged in her usual activities during this period. She was born at term and has been healthy. She is at the 60th percentile for height, 40th percentile for weight, and 90th percentile for head circumference. The patient is irritable and listless. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Ophthalmic examination shows bilateral optic disc swelling. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A cranial CT scan with contrast shows enlargement of the ventricular spaces as well as a 4-cm enhancing solid mass with scattered calcifications within the 4th ventricle. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) overproduction is a rare cause of hydrocephalus and only occurs due to choroid plexus tumors. A choroid plexus papilloma may manifest with communicating hydrocephalus and a solid mass that may be calcified. However, pediatric choroid plexus papillomas are typically seen in the lateral ventricles and are relatively rare, accounting for < 6% of intracranial tumors in this age group.

Unlike in the pediatric population, the most common site of a choroid plexus papilloma among adults is the fourth ventricle.

B) INCORRECT:

Cerebral edema is a complication of a variety of central nervous system diseases (e.g., stroke, infection, trauma), and often results in raised ICP, which manifests with headache, vomiting, and papilledema. Brain tumors may have surrounding parenchymal edema that can exacerbate raised ICP symptoms. However, cerebral edema does not result in enlarged ventricles. While some of this patient's symptoms can be attributed to edema, the majority are likely due to hydrocephalus.

C) INCORRECT:

A congenital failure of the foramen of Magendie to open is the underlying cause of Dandy-Walker malformation (DWM). DWM is characterized by cystic dilation of the fourth ventricle, cerebellar vermis hypoplasia, and hydrocephalus. This patient has no symptoms of cerebellar disease (e.g., ataxia), and there is no evidence of cerebellar hypoplasia on her CT scan. Moreover, symptoms of DWM usually appear within the first year of life, unlike this patient who presents at 3 years of age.
Image Description:

Cranial MRI of a young child (T2 weighted, sagittal view)

The posterior fossa and the pons appear cystic and hyperintense. The cerebellum also appears hypoplastic and the posterior fossa is enlarged.

This radiographic appearance suggests Dandy-Walker syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Impaired CSF reabsorption by the arachnoid granulations is seen in conditions associated with increased pressure in the dural venous sinuses (e.g., dural venous thrombosis). Dural venous sinus thrombosis in children may produce symptoms that are similar to this patient's, such as irritability, vomiting, and communicating hydrocephalus (dilation of all ventricles). However, dural venous thrombosis usually occurs in patients with pericranial infections (e.g., sinusitis, mastoiditis), hypercoagulable states, or following trauma. Moreover, patients have a cord-like hyperdensity within the dural sinus on CT scan.

E) CORRECT:

Ependymomas usually develop from the lining of the ventricular system and, if they grow large enough, will cause obstruction of CSF flow and consequent dilation of the ventricles proximal to the obstruction (obstructive hydrocephalus). This patient's tumor is in the fourth ventricle, which is the most common location for ependymoma in children and the last ventricle along the CSF pathway; as such, all ventricles become dilated with trapped CSF. Ependymomas typically appear as homogeneous enhancing masses on CT neuroimaging, often with cysts and calcifications. Ependymomas have a poor prognosis, especially when located in the posterior fossa. The next step in management for this patient would be a brain MRI to provide better images of the tumor. Treatment would likely involve surgical resection and possibly radiation therapy.
questions.hint: Dilation of the ventricles and signs of increased intracranial pressure (ICP), such as vomiting, papilledema, and irritability, indicate hydrocephalus. Hydrocephalus in a 3-year-old child with a mass in the 4th ventricle suggests an ependymoma.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for short stature. Neither his clothing nor his shoe size has changed over the past year. He also frequently bumps into obstacles such as furniture and has headaches at night. He is always thirsty for cold water and has been urinating more frequently. Three years ago, he had an asthma attack that was treated with albuterol and a one-week course of steroids. His mother has Hashimoto's thyroiditis and had precocious puberty. His mother's height is 147 cm (4 ft 10 in) and his father's height is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in). He is at the 5th percentile for height and 5th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 100/64 mm Hg. Examination shows a soft and nontender abdomen. The genitals and pubic hair are both Tanner stage 1. Axillary hair is absent. Patellar reflexes are 1+ bilaterally. Laboratory studies show:


Na+

145 mEq/L


K+

4.1 mEq/L


Cl-

102 mEq/L


HCO3-

25 mEq/L


Ca2+

9.4 mg/dL


Glucose
98 mg/dL


Thyroid-stimulating hormone
0.2 μU/mL


Thyroxine
3.9 μg/dL


Insulin-like growth factor 1

24 ng/mL (N= 61–356)


Insulin-like growth factor-binding protein 3
2.1 μg/mL (N = 1.6–6.5)


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Long-term corticosteroid therapy (e.g., for children with nephrotic syndrome) is known to cause short stature. However, children undergoing long-term steroid therapy would have a Cushingoid appearance characterized by obesity (unlike this child with a weight at the 5th percentile) and a moon-like facies. This child was only on a week-long course of corticosteroids, which would not result in a short stature.

B) INCORRECT:

An expanding Rathke cleft cyst can cause headaches, visual field defects, and multiple hormone deficiencies due to hypopituitarism. However, symptoms usually occur between the ages of 30–50 years.

C) INCORRECT:

Schmidt syndrome, the most common form of autoimmune polyendocrine syndrome, can manifest with decreased thyroxine levels (due to hypothyroidism) as well as polyuria and polydipsia (due to type 1 diabetes mellitus). However, Schmidt syndrome is more common among women between 20–60 years of age and is associated with elevated TSH levels (primary hypothyroidism). GH deficiency (suggested by decreased IGF-1 levels) and short stature would be unexpected. Moreover, normal serum glucose along with headache and visual field defects suggest that polyuria and polydipsia in this patient are caused by central diabetes insipidus rather than diabetes mellitus.

D) INCORRECT:

Constitutional growth delay is a diagnosis of exclusion that is made once other causes of short stature have been ruled out. A different cause for short stature is more likely on account of the presence of multiple hormone deficiencies, headache, and visual field defects.

E) INCORRECT:

Although a low mid-parental height suggests a diagnosis of familial short stature, which is one of the most common causes of short stature, the presence of multiple hormone deficiencies, headache, and visual field defects indicates a different diagnosis.

F) CORRECT:

Craniopharyngiomas are the most common cause of acquired hypopituitarism among children. This child presents with features of hypopituitarism such as growth hormone deficiency (as indicated by a low insulin-like growth factor 1 and short stature), diabetes insipidus (as indicated by polyuria and polydipsia), and secondary hypothyroidism (as indicated by hyporeflexia, low thyroid-stimulating hormone, and low thyroxine levels). Headache is caused by compression of the adjacent brain parenchyma and/or stretching of the dura mater, while visual field defects are the result of compression of the optic chiasm. A craniopharyngioma can be diagnosed by an MRI of the brain, which typically reveals a suprasellar mass that extends into the sella turcica. Craniopharyngiomas are excised surgically using a transfrontal approach.

G) INCORRECT:

Patients with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN 1) may develop pituitary adenomas, which can result in headaches, visual field defects, and multiple hormone deficiencies (due to destruction of the normal pituitary gland). However, pituitary adenomas in patients with MEN 1 usually develop during adulthood. In addition, by the time pituitary adenomas become symptomatic, patients almost always have increased serum calcium levels due to primary hyperparathyroidism, which is usually the earliest endocrine manifestation of MEN 1.

H) INCORRECT:

A large, nonsecretory pituitary adenoma may result in headaches, visual field defects, and multiple hormone deficiencies due to hypopituitarism. However, symptoms usually occur between the ages of 30–60 years. A different diagnosis is more likely in this 8-year-old boy.
questions.hint: This boy has symptoms and laboratory findings suggestive of multiple hormonal deficiencies (diabetes insipidus, secondary hypothyroidism, and growth hormone deficiency). The fact that the child frequently bumps into obstacles suggests that the child has a peripheral visual field defect.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of early morning headaches for the past 6 months. During this period, he has had severe nausea and occasional episodes of vomiting. For the past month, he has had difficulty walking and intermittent double vision. He was born at term and has been healthy apart from an episode of sinusitis 8 months ago that resolved spontaneously. He is at the 60th percentile for height and 50th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 105/64 mm Hg. Examination shows normal muscle strength and 2+ deep tendon reflexes bilaterally. He has a broad-based gait and impaired tandem gait. Fundoscopy shows bilateral swelling of the optic disc. There is esotropia of the left eye. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Optic gliomas may cause esotropia, visual impairment, and can potentially lead to increased intracranial pressure. However, these tumors are uncommon and would not cause ataxia.
Image Description:

MRI head (T2-weighted; axial plane)

There is a large hyperintense mass (green overlay) in the left intraconal space displacing the ocular globe out of the orbital cavity (exophthalmos). The intraconal space is located posterior to the globe and contained within the cone formed by the recti muscles. The mass is well-defined and displaces rather than invades surrounding structures. The left optic nerve is not visualized on this image, and the mass either arises from it or displaces it. The normal-appearing right optic nerve (red overlay) is well visualized.

The differential diagnosis for intraconal masses depends on whether or not the lesion is continuous with the optic nerve. Differential diagnoses for masses involving the optic nerve include, but are not limited to, meningioma, glioma, and lymphoma. Differential diagnoses for masses not involving the nerve include, but are not limited to, hemangioma, schwannoma, and rhabdomyosarcoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Schwannomas are most commonly located in the cerebellopontine angle (acoustic/vestibular schwannomas) and typically manifest with tinnitus, hearing loss, dizziness, and/or disequilibrium from cranial nerve VIII (CN VIII) compression. Although ataxia and hydrocephalus may result from compression of posterior fossa structures in late stages of the disease, this patient has no auditory symptoms (the onset of which would be insidious) and is uncharacteristically young (the median age is 50 years).
Image Description:

Acoustic neuromas are benign tumors that arise from Schwann cells and primarily originate within the vestibular portion of cranial nerve VIII. The tumor originates within the internal acoustic canal with variable extension into the cerebellopontine angle. Early symptoms occur due to pressure on the cochlear nerve (unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus) and vestibular nerve (dizziness, unsteady gait, disequilibrium). If the tumor further expands into the cerebellopontine angle, further symptoms arise due to compression of CN V (paresthesia, hypoesthesia, unilateral facial pain), CN VII (unilateral facial weakness), and the cerebellum (ataxia).

C) INCORRECT:

Pituitary adenomas may cause bitemporal hemianopsia from compression of the optic chiasm, hypopituitarism, or other syndromes from excess secretion of pituitary hormones. These tumors do not typically cause ataxia and are much more common in adults.
Image Description:

MRI head (T1-weighted; without contrast; sagittal plane) of a male patient with headache, retroorbital pressure, fatigue, and elevated serum prolactin

A large mass, which is isointense to gray matter, is seen in the area of the sella turcica (indicated by arrows).

Considering the patient's history, a prolactin-secreting macroadenoma (prolactinoma) of the pituitary gland is the most likely diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Craniopharyngiomas may present with headaches and vomiting (due to obstructive hydrocephalus and traction on surrounding structures), as well as visual symptoms (typically bitemporal hemianopsia from compression of the optic chiasm). However, the lack of additional symptoms, such as hyperprolactinemia/delayed growth or central diabetes insipidus from compression of the anterior or posterior pituitary gland, makes this diagnosis less likely. In addition, ataxia would be an uncommon finding in craniopharyngioma.
Image Description:

MRI head (T1 weighted; with contrast; sagittal plane) of a patient with acute visual loss in the right eye

There is an intrasellar and suprasellar mass (green overlay) with both cystic and solid portions. The solid portions show strong contrast enhancement.

E) INCORRECT:

Although hemangioblastoma may manifest with ataxia and increased intracranial pressure, these tumors are rare and most commonly occur in adults.
Image Description:

MRI head (with contrast; axial view)

A brightly enhancing, sharply delimited nodular mass (white arrow) with nonenhancing, cystic areas is visible within the right cerebellar hemisphere.

These findings are consistent with cerebellar hemangioblastoma.

F) INCORRECT:

While meningiomas are the most common primary central nervous system tumors in adults (with a peak incidence in the sixth decade of life), they are rarely found in children. Due to their slow growth, meningiomas are usually asymptomatic, but they may manifest with seizures or focal neurologic deficits resulting from compression or increased intracranial pressure due to obstructive hydrocephalus. They are not usually associated with ataxia.
Image Description:

MRI head (T1-weighted; with contrast; sagittal plane)

There is a well-circumscribed homogeneous mass (green overlay) along the cerebral convexity. It demonstrates intense, homogeneous enhancement, equivalent to that of adjacent dura mater. Displacement without invasion of the surrounding white matter supports an extra-axial location.

This is a case of meningioma, a dural-based tumor. The dura is represented in this image by the thin, discontinuously enhancing line covering the inner surface of the skull (indicated by arrowhead).

G) CORRECT:

Medulloblastoma is the most common malignant brain tumor in children, with a peak incidence between 3–5 years of age. The mass is characteristically located in the cerebellum. Patients typically present with symptoms of hydrocephalus/increased ICP and involvement of the cerebellar vermis such as vomiting, morning headaches, ataxia, and cranial nerve dysfunction. Spinal drop metastases are found in about 40% of cases.

Ependymomas are often located in the posterior fossa and may also manifest with signs of hydrocephalus, as well as ataxia and cranial nerve dysfunction. However, these tumors are less common than medulloblastomas, accounting for ∼ 10% of pediatric brain tumors.
Image Description:

Cranial MRI (T1-weighted, with contrast)

There is a mass in the posterior cranial fossa. It features solid parts (green overlay) and cystic parts (red overlay).

Location and appearance are typical of a medulloblastoma.

(D: diencephalon; P: pons; C: cerebellum; yellow outline: cerebellar tentorium)
questions.hint: This tumor is derived from primitive neuroectodermal tissue.

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-year history of increasing weakness of her extremities and neck pain that is worse on coughing or sneezing. She first noticed weakness of her right upper extremity 3 years ago, which progressed to her right lower extremity 2 years ago, her left lower extremity 1 year ago, and her left upper extremity 6 months ago. She has had difficulty swallowing and speaking for the past 5 months. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows an ataxic gait. Speech is dysarthritic. Muscular examination shows spasticity and muscle strength is decreased in all extremities. There is bilateral atrophy of the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles. Deep tendon reflexes are 4+ bilaterally. Plantar response shows an extensor response bilaterally. Sensation to touch is decreased over all extremities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Although the falx cerebri, the supratentorial convex surface, and the sphenoidal wings are the most common locations of meningiomas, in rare cases they also occur at the foramen magnum. Since meningiomas are slow-growing tumors, patients usually present after several months to years of slowly progressive symptoms. Early features include neck pain, which is typically worse with neck flexion and maneuvers that increase ICP (e.g., coughing, sneezing). Later, patients with meningiomas at the foramen magnum present with long tract signs and a characteristic pattern of symptom distribution: sensory and motor deficits typically start in one extremity and spread to the others. Late presentation is characterized by spastic quadriparesis (hyperreflexia, positive Babinski sign), gait disturbances, and lower cranial nerve palsies (CN IX–XII), which most likely accounts for this patient's dysarthria and atrophy of the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles.
Image Description:

MRI of the neck and base of the skull (left: T1-weighted, with contrast, sagittal plane; right: T2-weighted, sagittal plane)

There is a well-defined mass in the anterior aspect of the foramen magnum, which enhances on the T1-weighted post-contrast image (red overlay) and appears hyperintense to gray matter on the T2-weighted image (green overlay). The mass is continuous with the adjacent thickened and enhancing dura (arrowhead). This is known as the “dural tail sign.”

The dural tail sign suggests lesion originates from the dura mater. The sign is most commonly seen in meningiomas but may also be seen in other malignancies originating in the dura mater, such as lymphoma and metastasis.

B) INCORRECT:

Pilocytic astrocytomas are grade I (benign) astrocytomas that are often localized in the cerebellum and most frequently occur in children and young adults. Signs of cerebellar masses include symptoms of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., headache, nausea, and vomiting), ataxia, and possibly failure to thrive. While an ataxic gait could be caused by a cerebellar tumor, this patient's muscle weakness, sensory symptoms, and dysarthria suggest another diagnosis.
Image Description:

MRI head (a: T1-weighted; with contrast; sagittal plane; b: T2-weighted; axial plane) of a child

A large lesion in the right cerebellar hemisphere displaces the vermis to the left of midline. It has a large cystic component (T1 hypointense and T2 hyperintense; red overlay) and a heterogeneously enhancing solid nodular component (green overlay).

Cerebellar pilocytic astrocytoma frequently manifests as a large cystic lesion with an enhancing mural nodule.

C) INCORRECT:

In syringomyelia, the compression from the fluid-filled cavity within the central spinal cord results in neck pain and a cape-like distribution (neck, shoulders, arms) of dissociated sensory loss, which develops over years. The sensory symptoms in syringomyelia are often exacerbated by maneuvers that increase the intramedullary pressure, such as coughing or sneezing. Muscle atrophy is another common feature of syringomyelia and most commonly affects the small muscles of the hand. Other signs of lower motor neuron lesion, such as fasciculations and areflexia (rather than this patient's hyperreflexia), may also be present. While spastic paraparesis of the limbs is a possible feature of syringomyelia due to involvement of the pyramidal tract and first motor neuron, quadriparesis is uncommon.

D) INCORRECT:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) manifests with signs of upper motor neuron (e.g., hyperreflexia, spastic paresis, positive Babinski sign) and lower motor neuron involvement (e.g., atrophy), both of which are present in this patient. ALS may also initially manifest with bulbar symptoms (e.g., dysarthria, dysphagia) and/or asymmetrical limb weakness, which often begins unilaterally in an upper extremity and progresses with the disease. However, this patient's sensory symptoms are not consistent with ALS, which is a motor neuron disease.
Image Description:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a neurodegenerative disease that affects the entire motor neuron system (degeneration of the upper motor neuron in the precentral gyrus and lower motor neuron in the brainstem or anterior horn of the spinal cord). The disease most commonly manifests between 50 and 70 years of age, often beginning with unilateral weakness in the hands or feet, which then progresses to the contralateral side (asymmetric limb weakness). However, initial manifestations are highly variable and individuals may have atypical or nonspecific symptoms such as subtle vocal changes. As the disease progresses, most individuals eventually develop one or both of the life-threatening symptoms: respiratory impairment and dysphagia.

E) INCORRECT:

In multiple sclerosis (MS), demyelination of CNS neurons may result in upper motor neuron weakness characterized by spasticity, hyperreflexia, and a positive Babinski sign. Dysarthria is also present in almost half of all MS cases at some point during the course of the disease. However, the most common course of MS is relapsing-remitting, which progresses with alternating phases of exacerbations and remission rather than simply progressive. Also, atrophy of the muscles innervated by cranial nerve XI is not a typical feature of MS.
Image Description:

MRI cervical spine (T2-weighted; sagittal plane)

At the level of the fourth cervical vertebral body, there is an area of poorly defined hyperintensity within the spinal cord (green overlay). The first cervical vertebra is not well visualized in this image due to its shape, whereas the second cervical vertebra is well recognized due to the superior projected bony element known as the dens or odontoid process.

This is an example of a demyelinating plaque in a patient with multiple sclerosis. Spinal cord demyelinating plaques from multiple sclerosis are most often found in the cervical segment of the cord. They are usually shorter than two vertebral bodies in length.

F) INCORRECT:

A glioblastoma multiforme is most commonly located in the white matter of the cerebral hemispheres and therefore most frequently manifests with signs of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., headache, seizures). Symptoms develop over a short period of time (several weeks) due to rapid growth of the tumor. While the condition can manifest with motor weakness, the pattern of symptom progression over 3 years seen in this patient is not consistent with glioblastoma multiforme.
Image Description:

T1-weighted contrast-enhanced MRI, frontal view: bihemisphere garland-like contrast enhancement. There is peripheral contrast agent enhancement (blue overlay) with central necrosis (green overlay). The third ventricle (arrowhead) is centrally located. The tumor is displacing the posterior horn of the lateral ventricle (red overlay). Diagnosis: bilateral glioblastoma (butterfly glioma).
questions.hint: The pattern of this patient's symptom progression suggests CNS compression in a particular location.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her husband for the evaluation of confusion and memory deficits for the last month. During this period, she has also had mild weakness in her left leg. She has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Her current medications include enalapril and atorvastatin. She has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for the last 45 years. She drinks a glass of wine every day. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg. She is oriented only to person. She recalls 2 out of 3 objects immediately and none after 5 minutes. The patient is unable to lift her eyebrows or smile. Muscle strength is decreased in the left lower extremity. A T2-weighted MRI scan of the head shows several hyperintense round lesions in the frontal and temporal lobes at the border of the gray and white matter. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) may present with decreased cognitive function, focal neurological deficits, and multifocal hyperintense lesions on T2-weighted MRI. However, PML almost exclusively develops in patients with severe immunosuppression (e.g., AIDS, patients on immunosuppressive therapy). This patient does not have any clinical feature to suggest immunosuppression (e.g., oral candidiasis), and has not received any form of immunosuppressive therapy.
Image Description:

MRI Head (A: T2 weighted, B: T1 weighted with contrast; axial plane)

A T2 hyperintense lesion without mass effect (image A, green overlay) in the left cerebellar hemisphere does not enhance on the T1 weighted sequence (image B). Other enhancing foci (red overlay) are seen in B, although such enhancement is uncommon in PML.

PML lesions typically involve parietooccipital subcortical and periventricular white matter, are T2 hyperintense, do not enhance, and produce little or no mass effect.

B) INCORRECT:

Glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) is one of the most common and lethal primary brain tumors in adults between 45–70 years of age. While progressive focal deficits are not uncommon, the majority of cases present with headaches. Furthermore, MRI typically shows a large unifocal lesion, unlike multifocal lesions of brain metastases.
Image Description:

MRI brain (T1-weighted; with contrast; axial plane) of a 69-year-old patient with personality changes and left-sided hemiparesis.

In the white matter of the right hemisphere, there is a large, poorly circumscribed space-occupying lesion, which is hypointense centrally (green overlay) with strong peripheral contrast enhancement (red overlay). The lesion is surrounded by edema (white overlay), suggesting rapid growth and displacement of surrounding structures. The mass effect has also caused a slight midline shift to the contralateral side (white dashed line), and compression of the right lateral ventricle (white arrowheads indicate anterior horn compression).

These radiographic features are typical of a glioblastoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Multiple sclerosis may present with cognitive impairment, focal neurological deficits, and multifocal hyperintense lesions on T2-weighted MRI. However, the symptoms of multiple sclerosis usually begin between the ages of 20–40 years, and the clinical course is typically characterized by exacerbations and remissions.
Image Description:

MRI head (T2-weighted; axial plane)

Extensive bilateral demyelinating lesions (plaques) appear as hyperintensities in the periventricular white matter (green overlay). Radial extensions of these lesions (Dawson fingers) are visible. Generalized cerebral atrophy, part of the disease process for multiple sclerosis, is also visible.

D) INCORRECT:

Meningiomas, which are the most common primary brain tumors in adults, may present with focal neurological deficits and have a hyperintense appearance on a T2-weighted MRI. However, meningiomas usually appear as unifocal extra-axial space-occupying lesions, unlike in this patient with multiple intra-axial lesions at the junction of the gray and white matter.
Image Description:

MRI head (T1-weighted; with contrast; sagittal plane)

There is a well-circumscribed homogeneous mass (green overlay) along the cerebral convexity. It demonstrates intense, homogeneous enhancement, equivalent to that of adjacent dura mater. Displacement without invasion of the surrounding white matter supports an extra-axial location.

This is a case of meningioma, a dural-based tumor. The dura is represented in this image by the thin, discontinuously enhancing line covering the inner surface of the skull (indicated by arrowhead).

E) INCORRECT:

Colorectal cancer is the third most common cancer in the US. Risk factors include smoking and alcohol consumption. While brain metastases are possible, initial metastases are usually to the liver or lungs. Tumors arising from the proximal rectum usually metastasize via the portal system to the liver, while tumors of the distal rectum metastasize via the inferior rectal vein to the inferior vena cava and thus the lungs.

F) INCORRECT:

Malignant melanoma is the third most common primary tumor in patients with brain metastases. However, this patient does not have any cutaneous lesions, nor risk factors associated with melanomas (e.g., chronic sun exposure, family history, immunosuppression). Moreover, intracranial metastases caused by malignant melanomas typically appear hypointense on T2-weighted imaging.

G) CORRECT:

Lung cancer is the second most common cancer in the US, especially in women ≥ 60 years with a history of cigarette smoking. Lung cancer is also the single most common source of brain metastases, which cause a variety of symptoms, including progressively worsening cognitive dysfunction and focal neurological deficits.
Image Description:

CT head (with contrast; axial plane) of a patient with a history of lung cancer presenting with weight loss, gradual reduction in consciousness, and deficits in swallowing, speech, coordination, and gait

Cerebellar (green overlay) and brainstem (red overlay) lesions that show intense contrast enhancement are suspicious for metastases.

P: petrous bone; S: sphenoid bone; T with arrows: tentorium cerebellum
questions.hint: This patient presents with several round lesions at the border of the gray and white matter of the brain, suggesting brain metastases.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman comes to the physician because of headaches for 1 month. She describes them as 7 out of 10 in intensity. She has no nausea. Two years ago, she was treated for invasive lobular carcinoma of the left breast. She underwent a left mastectomy and multiple cycles of chemotherapy. She has been in good health since this treatment. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 118/72 mm Hg. There is a well-healed scar on the left side of the chest. There is no lymphadenopathy. The abdomen is soft and nontender; there is no organomegaly. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. An MRI of the brain shows a 4-cm temporal hyperintense mass near the surface of the brain. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Whole brain radiation therapy (WBRT) is the treatment of choice for patients with either multiple brain metastases or a poor prognosis. Consequences of WBRT include fatigue and alopecia in addition to neurocognitive deterioration months after therapy. Since this patient has a single metastasis with good functional status and no systemic disease, WBRT would not be indicated at this time. While WBRT was once commonly used following surgical resection to minimize local recurrence, focal radiation therapy (which has far fewer side effects) has largely replaced this treatment modality in postoperative patients.

B) CORRECT:

Surgical resection has been shown to improve both survival and quality of life in patients with a single brain metastasis. This patient is a good surgical candidate as she has a good functional status with no evidence of other metastases, and her tumor is surgically accessible (near the surface of the brain). The goal of surgery is twofold: symptomatic relief (i.e. reduction of this patient's headaches) and local control (i.e. prevention of local recurrence). Postoperative focal radiation is commonly employed to reduce the local recurrence risk, although there are doubts as to whether this improves overall survival.

C) INCORRECT:

Chemotherapy is a useful palliative treatment modality for patients with multiple or recurrent brain metastases. However, since this patient has a single brain mass with no signs of systemic disease, chemotherapy would not be the first-line treatment in this situation.

D) INCORRECT:

Antibiotic therapy is an essential component in the treatment of patients with brain abscesses, which can also present with headaches and masses on MRI. However, about half of these patients also have fever or neurologic deficits. Often brain abscesses arise via hematogenous or direct spread, so many of the patients affected have a concurrent infection. Although brain abscesses can also arise without concurrent infection, this patient's recent history of breast cancer increases the likelihood that her brain lesion is a metastatic tumor (that would not respond to antibiotics).

E) INCORRECT:

Palliative care may be indicated in patients with a high tumor burden, poor prognosis, and/or poor functional status. Patients with a single brain metastasis tend to have a poor overall prognosis (< 3 months survival without treatment), but surgical resection can significantly reduce symptoms and increase survival to ∼ 1 year. Thus, as this patient has a metastatic tumor with good functional status and no evidence of systemic disease, palliative care is inappropriate at this time.
questions.hint: The presence of headaches and a brain mass in a woman who was treated previously for breast cancer is suspicious for a brain metastasis.

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl is brought to her primary care physician because of a 4-month history of early morning headaches and worsening fatigue. The headaches are often accompanied by nausea and sometimes relieved by vomiting. She stopped going to her ballet lessons 2 weeks ago because she was embarrassed about falling frequently and having increasing difficulty performing the steps. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 105/65 mm Hg. She has a broad-based gait. While standing with both feet together and raising her arms, closing her eyes does not affect her balance. She is unable to perform rapid, alternating movements with her hands. An MRI of the brain is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acoustic schwannomas can present with vertigo and/or dizziness that result in falls. However, patients will more commonly present with sensorineural hearing loss, which this patient lacks. More importantly, acoustic neuromas are found within the internal acoustic canal along CN VIII or within the cerebral hemispheres. Imaging for acoustic schwannoma would also show a cystic lesion with nodular parts. Finally, acoustic schwannomas occur rarely in children.
Image Description:

Cranial MRI
Upper left: T2-weighted image (axial view)
Lower left and right: T1-weighted images after application of contrast agent (axial and coronal views)

A tumor is visible on the right side between the brainstem and the cerebellum (green overlay), extending into the porus acousticus (arrow). There is strong contrast enhancement within the lesion and it has a hypointense center (red overlay), suggesting necrosis.

B) CORRECT:

Pilocytic astrocytoma is the most common brain tumor in children and is usually located within the posterior fossa. Cerebellar compression can cause falls and dysdiadochokinesia, while increased intracranial pressure can result in lethargy, morning headaches, nausea, and vomiting. Imaging typically shows a well-circumscribed, enhancing cystic mass within one of the cerebellar hemispheres, but it can also occur in the cerebral hemispheres. Since pilocytic astrocytomas are low-grade tumors (WHO grade I), patients usually have a favorable prognosis following surgical resection.

Medulloblastoma and pilocytic astrocytoma are the most common posterior cranial fossa tumors in children. Medulloblastoma is the most common malignant brain tumor in children.

C) INCORRECT:

Oligodendroglioma can cause signs of increased intracranial pressure. However, these tumors are usually located supratentorial rather than in the posterior fossa, which is why patients with oligodendroglioma tend to also have seizures and/or focal neurological deficits. Furthermore, oligodendrogliomas usually affect adults 40–50 years of age, not children.
Image Description:

Cranial CT scan (axial view)

A large hypodense lesion (green overlay) with multiple intralesional hyperdense calcifications (yellow overlay) is visible in the temporal lobe.

D) INCORRECT:

Brainstem glioma can cause signs of increased intracranial pressure (i.e., morning headaches, nausea, and vomiting) and cerebellar signs (broad-based gait, dysdiadochokinesia). However, due to brainstem involvement in this condition, cranial nerve deficits are typically seen (e.g., diplopia, facial droop) and symptoms usually develop over the course of a few days, not months. Imaging usually shows minimal contrast enhancement rather than a contrast-enhancing cystic mass.

E) INCORRECT:

Craniopharyngiomas can present with signs of increased intracranial pressure (i.e., morning headaches, nausea, and vomiting), but are located within the sellar or suprasellar region, not the posterior fossa. Additionally, this patient lacks other findings of craniopharyngioma, such as vision changes from optic chiasm compression (e.g., bitemporal hemianopsia) and/or hormonal imbalances from pituitary compression (e.g., short stature, delayed puberty). Also, ataxia is not seen with this type of tumor.

F) INCORRECT:

Ependymoma can cause signs of increased intracranial pressure (i.e., morning headaches, nausea, and vomiting) and cerebellar signs (broad-based gait, dysdiadochokinesia). However, these tumors typically arise from the floor of the fourth ventricle, adapt to the shape of the ventricle, and extend through the foramina of Luschka and Magendi into the cisterns. It would be unusual for the tumor not to invade the ventricles and have cystic components on imaging. Furthermore, patients with ependymomas tend to be younger than this patient.
Image Description:

MRI brain (FLAIR; sagittal view)

A well-defined heterogeneous hyperintense lesion is visible within the expanded 4th ventricle (green overlay). At the superior aspect of the lesion, multiple dark foci are present (arrowheads), representing cysts. They appear dark in this image as the fluid signal is removed on FLAIR sequences. This lesion has obstructed circulation of the cerebrospinal fluid, resulting in ventriculomegaly (indicated by dashed line).

Ependymomas commonly arise within the fourth ventricle. They are usually hyperintense on T2 weighted/FLAIR images and can demonstrate cystic change, such as in this case, as well as hemorrhage.
questions.hint: The MRI scan shows a large (3.5 cm), well-defined, contrast-enhancing cystic mass in the lateral posterior fossa without ventricular involvement.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the hospital because of blurred vision and headache for 3 months. During this period, the father noticed that the child has been tilting his head back to look straight ahead. The patient has also had difficulty falling asleep for 2 months. He has had a 3.5 kg (7.7 lb) weight loss over the past 6 months. His temperature is 37.7°C (99.8°F), pulse is 105/min, and blood pressure is 104/62 mm Hg. Examination shows equal pupils that are not reactive to light. The pupils constrict when an object is brought near the eye. His upward gaze is impaired; there is bilateral nystagmus and eyelid retraction while attempting to look upwards. Neurologic examination shows no other focal findings. The remainder of the examination shows no other abnormalities. If left untreated, which of the following is the most likely sequela of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Leukocoria is a typical manifestation of retinoblastoma, which may cause nystagmus and loss of vision. However, the age of onset of retinoblastoma is typically < 4 years and this patient does not have strabismus, which is the most common initial manifestation. Parinaud syndrome and insomnia are not typical features of retinoblastoma. Moreover, leukocoria is a clinical finding and not a sequela of any medical condition.

Rarely, individuals with retinoblastoma may have an ectopic tumor in the pineal gland (i.e., trilateral retinoblastoma), causing Parinaud syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Pretibial myxedema is a sequela of Graves disease, which may manifest with weight loss, ocular symptoms (e.g., lid retraction), and insomnia. However, in contrast to this patient's ocular findings, Graves ophthalmopathy manifests with bilateral exophthalmos and conjunctival hyperemia, not with vertical gaze palsy. Moreover, this patient does not have other characteristic symptoms of hyperthyroidism, such as excessive sweating, tachycardia, and diffuse goiter.

C) INCORRECT:

Growth failure can result from compression of the pituitary gland due to intrasellar extension of a craniopharyngioma. Headaches, caused by compression of the adjacent brain parenchyma and/or stretching of the dura mater, and visual field defects (e.g., bilateral hemianopia), resulting from compression of the optic chiasm, are common in this condition. This patient most likely has a pinealoma, which can compress the hypothalamic inhibiting pathways and subsequently increase hCG secretion, leading to precocious puberty rather than growth failure.

D) CORRECT:

Parinaud syndrome occurs in most patients with pinealomas and is caused by compression of the tectum and the medial longitudinal fasciculus, which together coordinate eye movements. If left untreated, a pinealoma may obstruct the passage of cerebrospinal fluid from the ventricles to the subarachnoid space (e.g., via aqueductal stenosis) leading to obstructive hydrocephalus, a common sequela of pinealoma. Obstructive hydrocephalus typically manifests with headaches, vision abnormalities, nausea, vomiting, and impaired ambulation (e.g, ataxia) due to increased intracranial pressure.

The most common type of pinealoma in children is a pineal germinoma that typically secretes β-hCG, eventually leading to precocious puberty.

E) INCORRECT:

Opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome (OMS) is a paraneoplastic syndrome that may develop in individuals with neuroblastoma. While weight loss and ocular anomalies (e.g., proptosis) may be present in individuals with neuroblastoma, it does not cause vertical gaze palsy, nystagmus, or Collier sign. Also, this patient has no features suggesting neuroblastoma, such as abdominal distension, bone pain, and a palpable, firm, irregular abdominal mass that crosses the midline.
questions.hint: This patient has vertical gaze palsy, nystagmus, eyelid retraction on looking upward (Collier sign), and pupils that accommodate but do not react to light, which suggests Parinaud syndrome. Additional symptoms of weight loss, headache, and insomnia raise suspicion for pinealoma.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man comes to the physician because of headaches and blurry vision for the past 6 months. He also reports frequent episodes of vomiting over the last month. His father died of renal cell carcinoma at the age of 37 years. Examination shows 20/40 vision bilaterally. Fundoscopic examination shows bilateral optic disc swelling and growth of capillary vessels in the temporal peripheral retina. An MRI of the brain shows an infratentorial mass. The patient undergoes surgical resection of the mass. A photomicrograph of the resected specimen is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Medulloblastomas, which are commonly located in the infratentorial region, may present with features of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., headache, vomiting, blurred vision, papilledema). However, they are not associated with retinal vascular changes. In addition, this type of tumor most commonly develops in the first decade of life. Histology typically shows small round blue cells and Homer-Wright rosettes, which are not seen in this patient's photomicrograph. Finally, medulloblastomas are not a manifestation of VHL disease but instead are associated with Turcot's syndrome.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of cerebellar vermis tissue (H&E stain)

Numerous small, blue, round cells with scant cytoplasm can be seen throughout the specimen (examples indicated by green overlay). Their nuclei vary in size and structure (nuclear pleomorphism) and many cells feature distinctly hyperchromatic nuclei.
The majority of the cells are arranged in concentric clusters around lighter central areas consisting of neuropil (examples indicated by yellow overlay). These clusters are referred to as Homer Wright rosettes.

These histopathological features, particularly the Homer Wright rosettes, are characteristic of a medulloblastoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Pilocytic astrocytomas, which are commonly located in the infratentorial region, may present with features of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., headache, vomiting, blurred vision, papilledema). However, they are not associated with retinal vascular changes. Moreover, this type of tumor most commonly develops in patients younger than 20 years of age. Histology typically shows Rosenthal fibers and positive staining for glial fibrillary acidic protein, which are not seen in this patient's photomicrograph. Finally, pilocytic astrocytomas are not a manifestation of VHL disease but instead are associated with neurofibromatosis type 1.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of cerebellar tissue (H&E stain)

There are numerous bipolar cells, composed of a central basophilic nucleus with eosinophilic pilocytic processes (examples indicated in green) arising from either end. The pilocytic processes are arranged in bundles, which resemble matted hair. The bright red-pink bodies are intracytoplasmic inclusions (examples indicated by black arrowheads) in astrocytes and indicate intense gliosis (Rosenthal fibers).

These are the characteristic features of pilocytic astrocytoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Craniopharyngiomas can present with headache and vomiting, as seen here. However, as opposed to this patient's tumor, this type of neoplasm is located in the supratentorial (i.e., suprasellar) region. Moreover, craniopharyngiomas are usually associated with bitemporal hemianopsia, hyperprolactinemia, and hypopituitarism, all of which are absent here. Histology typically shows metaplastic squamous cells or reticular epithelial cells, calcifications, cysts, and keratin nodules, none of which are seen in this patient's photomicrograph. Finally, craniopharyngiomas are not a manifestation of von Hippel-Lindau disease.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a brain tissue sample (HPS stain; intermediate magnification)

Trabeculae and nests of squamous epithelium (examples indicated by yellow overlay) with palisading cells (examples indicated by blue hatched overlay) are visible.
Additionally, there are multiple cysts (examples indicated by yellow hatched overlay), nodules of anuclear ghost cells (examples indicated by blue overlay) containing wet keratin, and calcifications (examples indicated by blue outline) .

This is the typical histological appearance of an adamantinomatous craniopharyngioma.

D) INCORRECT:

Glioblastomas can present with features of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., headache, vomiting, blurred vision, papilledema), as seen in this patient. However, as opposed to this patient's tumor, this type of neoplasm is located in the cerebral hemispheres (i.e., supratentorial). Consequently, symptoms such as seizures, focal neurological deficits, and personality changes are common, none of which are present in this patient. Moreover, the median age of onset is between 65–75 years of age. Histology typically shows pleomorphic anaplastic cells that form pseudopalisades and positive staining for glial fibrillary acidic protein, which are not seen in this patient's photomicrograph. Finally, glioblastomas are not a manifestation of von Hippel-Lindau disease.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a cerebral tissue specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)

A high number and density of highly pleomorphic cells with hyperchromatic and irregular nuclei are visible (examples indicated by arrowheads. These cells are aggregated around the periphery of the necrotic zone (green overlay), forming a nuclear pseudopalisading architecture.

These are the characteristic features of glioblastoma multiforme.

E) INCORRECT:

Oligodendrogliomas can present with headache and vomiting. However, as opposed to this patient's tumor, this type of neoplasm is most commonly located in the cerebral hemispheres (i.e., supratentorial). Consequently, symptoms such as seizures, focal neurological deficits, and personality changes are common, none of which are present in this patient. Moreover, the median age of onset is between 40–50 years of age. Histology typically shows fried egg cells and a chicken-wire pattern of capillary anastomoses, which are not seen in this patient's photomicrograph. Finally, oligodendrogliomas are not a manifestation of von Hippel-Lindau disease.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of brain tissue (H&E stain; very high magnification)

Monomorphic cells with enlarged, round/oval nuclei surrounded by a clear halo of unstained cytoplasm, which is an artifact of processing, are visible (green overlay). Thin blood vessels with an interlacing pattern are also visible (yellow overlay).

These are the typical features of oligodendroglioma.

F) CORRECT:

Hemangioblastomas are rare, highly vascularized, infratentorial brain tumors, that may occur sporadically or as a manifestation of VHL disease. As in this case, patients often present with features of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., headache, vomiting, blurred vision, papilledema). Hemangioblastomas are further associated with polycythemia, caused by paraneoplastic erythropoietin production. Histology shows densely packed, thin-walled capillary vessels surrounded by large stromal cells with intracytoplasmic lipid inclusions. VHL-associated tumors most commonly occur in early adulthood and include hemangioblastomas of the spine, cerebellum, and retina (commonly bilateral and peripherally located, as seen here), renal cell carcinomas, pheochromocytomas, and pancreatic cysts.

G) INCORRECT:

Intracranial ependymomas, which are commonly located in the infratentorial region, may present with features of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., headache, vomiting, blurred vision, papilledema). However, they are not associated with retinal vascular changes. Moreover, this type of tumor most commonly develops in early childhood. Histology typically shows perivascular pseudorosettes and rod-shaped blepharoplasts, which are not seen in this patient's photomicrograph. Finally, ependymomas are not a manifestation of VHL disease but instead are associated with neurofibromatosis type 2.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a brain tumor tissue specimen (H&E stain; low magnification)

There is an abnormally high number of cells with round nuclei and abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm. Some cells are arranged in a spoke-and-wheel pattern, surrounding an empty central space. Such patterns are called ependymal rosettes (example indicated by green overlay). Other cells are arranged concentrically around blood vessels, producing a similar appearance (perivascular pseudorosettes; example indicated yellow overlay).

These are typical histopathological features of ependymoma.
questions.hint: This patient presents with an infratentorial brain tumor and abnormal capillary growth in the retina. In combination with a family history of renal cell carcinoma, this raises suspicion for von Hippel-Lindau disease (VHL).

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the physician for evaluation of 2 months of progressive clumsiness, falls, and increased urinary frequency. Physical examination shows bilateral temporal visual field loss. An MRI of the head shows a small calcified suprasellar mass. The patient undergoes surgery with complete removal of the mass. Pathological examination of the specimen shows a lobular tumor composed of cysts filled with oily, brownish-yellow fluid. This mass is most likely derived from which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Craniopharyngiomas are derived from remnants of the Rathke pouch, which is an ectodermal outpouching of the pharyngeal roof that develops into the anterior pituitary gland. Compression of the optic chiasm by the craniopharyngioma causes bitemporal hemianopsia and possibly, clumsiness or frequent tripping due to the visual field defect. Destruction of the posterior pituitary by the tumor results in central diabetes insipidus, which explains the increased urinary frequency in this patient.
Image Description:

MRI head (T1 weighted; with contrast; sagittal plane) of a patient with acute visual loss in the right eye

There is an intrasellar and suprasellar mass (green overlay) with both cystic and solid portions. The solid portions show strong contrast enhancement.

B) INCORRECT:

Medulloblastomas, which are the most common malignant brain tumor in children, originate from the primitive neuroectoderm and can cause clumsiness, frequent falls, and urinary symptoms (e.g., frequency, incontinence). However, medulloblastomas typically occur in the cerebellum, unlike the suprasellar tumor that is seen here. Also, bitemporal hemianopsia would not be expected and patients with urinary symptoms due to a medulloblastoma would also have evidence of raised intracranial pressure (e.g., headache, vomiting, papilledema) and ventriculomegaly on imaging due to obstructive hydrocephalus. Biopsy of a medulloblastoma would show small blue cells arranged around a neuropil (Homer-Wright rosettes).
Image Description:

Head MRI (T2 weighted image)

Medulloblastoma within the posterior cranial fossa (green border in overlay). The lesion contains cystic areas, particularly on the left side (green overlay).

C) INCORRECT:

Arachnoid cells give rise to meningiomas. A parasagittal meningioma can cause falls and clumsiness (due to spastic lower limb weakness) and urinary symptoms (e.g., frequency, incontinence). However, meningiomas typically occur in adults; they are extremely rare in children. Moreover, meningiomas are characterized on histopathology by layers of densely packed syncytial tumor cells, often arranged in whorls, interspersed spindle cells, and psammoma bodies.
Image Description:

MRI head (T1-weighted; with contrast; sagittal plane)

There is a well-circumscribed homogeneous mass (green overlay) along the cerebral convexity. It demonstrates intense, homogeneous enhancement, equivalent to that of adjacent dura mater. Displacement without invasion of the surrounding white matter supports an extra-axial location.

This is a case of meningioma, a dural-based tumor. The dura is represented in this image by the thin, discontinuously enhancing line covering the inner surface of the skull (indicated by arrowhead).

D) INCORRECT:

Astrocytomas arise from astroglial cells. A pilocytic astrocytoma, which is the most common primary brain tumor in childhood, can cause clumsiness, frequent falls, and urinary symptoms (e.g., frequency, incontinence). However, a pilocytic astrocytoma is typically located in the posterior cranial fossa (e.g., cerebellum), unlike the suprasellar tumor that is seen here. Also, bitemporal hemianopsia would not be expected and patients with urinary symptoms due to a pilocytic astrocytoma would also have evidence of raised intracranial pressure (e.g., headache, vomiting, papilledema) and ventriculomegaly on imaging due to obstructive hydrocephalus. Biopsy of a pilocytic astrocytoma would show Rosenthal fibers, which stain positive for glial fibrillary acid protein (GFAP).
Image Description:

MRI head (a: T1-weighted; with contrast; sagittal plane; b: T2-weighted; axial plane) of a child

A large lesion in the right cerebellar hemisphere displaces the vermis to the left of midline. It has a large cystic component (T1 hypointense and T2 hyperintense; red overlay) and a heterogeneously enhancing solid nodular component (green overlay).

Cerebellar pilocytic astrocytoma frequently manifests as a large cystic lesion with an enhancing mural nodule.

E) INCORRECT:

Lactotroph cells can give rise to prolactinomas, which could also manifest with urinary frequency (due to central diabetes insipidus), bitemporal hemianopsia, and a history of clumsiness or frequent tripping due to the visual field defect. However, prolactinomas arise within the sella turcica unlike the suprasellar mass that is seen here and this patient does not have any features of hyperprolactinemia (e.g., gynecomastia). Moreover, prolactinomas are usually seen in adults (35–60 years), not in children, and histopathology would show acidophilic lactotrophs displacing the other endocrine pituitary cells, not a cystic mass filled with dark, oily fluid.
Image Description:

MRI head (T1-weighted; left: sagittal plane; right: coronal plane) of a 21-year-old, male patient with a pituitary macroadenoma

A large, lobulated mass (green overlay) with heterogeneous contrast enhancement extends from the sella turcica into the suprasellar space.

Blue overlay: compressed third ventricle

F) INCORRECT:

Ependymomas can arise from the modified ependymal cells that line the walls of cerebral ventricles. An ependymoma can cause hydrocephalus, which could present with clumsiness, frequent falls, and urinary symptoms (e.g., frequency, incontinence). However, ependymomas typically arise infratentorially within the 4th ventricle. The 3rd ventricle, which is located in the suprasellar region, is an unusual location for an ependymoma. Moreover, bitemporal hemianopsia would not be expected. Instead, patients would have evidence of raised intracranial pressure (e.g., headache, vomiting, papilledema) and ventriculomegaly on imaging. Histopathology would show perivascular pseudorosettes and rod-shaped blepharoplasts (basal ciliary bodies).
Image Description:

MRI brain (FLAIR; sagittal view)

A well-defined heterogeneous hyperintense lesion is visible within the expanded 4th ventricle (green overlay). At the superior aspect of the lesion, multiple dark foci are present (arrowheads), representing cysts. They appear dark in this image as the fluid signal is removed on FLAIR sequences. This lesion has obstructed circulation of the cerebrospinal fluid, resulting in ventriculomegaly (indicated by dashed line).

Ependymomas commonly arise within the fourth ventricle. They are usually hyperintense on T2 weighted/FLAIR images and can demonstrate cystic change, such as in this case, as well as hemorrhage.
questions.hint: This child's bitemporal hemianopia and the MRI showing a calcified suprasellar mass are highly suggestive of craniopharyngioma, the most common supratentorial tumor in children. The histopathologic findings of a cystic mass filled with dark, oily fluid (“motor oil-like”) confirm this diagnosis.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 4-week history of worsening headache, nausea, and vomiting. The headache is worse at night. Fundoscopic examination shows swelling of the optic discs. A CT scan of the brain shows a heterogeneous, hyperintense, intraventricular mass. The patient undergoes surgical excision of the mass. Pathologic examination of the surgical specimen confirms that the tumor is of neuronal origin. The cells in this specimen are most likely to stain positive for which of the following immunohistochemical markers?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

S-100 is an immunohistochemical marker that identifies cells of neural crest origin. Tumors of neural crest origin that stain positive for S-100 include pheochromocytoma (from chromaffin cells), melanoma, schwannoma, and Langerhans cell histiocytosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Desmin is an immunohistochemical marker that identifies muscle cells. Tumors of muscle cell origin that stain positive for desmin include rhabdomyosarcoma.

C) CORRECT:

Synaptophysin is an immunohistochemical marker that identifies tumors derived from neuronal cells, e.g., neuroendocrine cells, which contain numerous synaptic vesicles. Tumors that stain positive with synaptophysin include neurocytomas, medulloblastomas, small cell carcinomas of the lung, and carcinoid tumors. Neurons also stain positive for neurofilaments, which are part of the neuronal cytoskeleton.

D) INCORRECT:

Glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) is an immunohistochemical marker that identifies cells of glial cell origin, which are non-neuronal cells of the central nervous system. Tumors of glial cell origin that stain positive for GFAP include astrocytoma and glioblastoma.

E) INCORRECT:

Cytokeratin is an immunohistochemical marker that identifies cells of epithelial origin. Tumors of epithelial cell origin that stain positive for cytokeratin include squamous cell carcinoma.
questions.hint: While the vast majority of malignant primary brain tumors in adults derive from glial cells, some brain tumors originate from neuroendocrine cells, which stain positive for a glycoprotein found in neuronal vesicles.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 2-month history of headaches. He is at the 25th percentile for weight and 80th percentile for height. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. CT scan of the head shows a small suprasellar cystic mass compressing the infundibular stalk. Serum concentration of which of the following hormones is most likely to be increased in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The luteinizing hormone (LH) is produced by the gonadotropic cells of the anterior pituitary, under the influence of GnRH. Increased LH levels are typically seen with hypergonadotropic hypogonadism and PCOS. A subclinical increase in LH levels also occurs in about a third of patients with gonadotropic pituitary adenomas, which can cause a headache. A pituitary adenoma would, however, arise within the sella turcica unlike the suprasellar mass in this patient. In this patient, the levels of LH would be expected to be low due to the inhibition of GnRH secretion by the hormone that is increased in concentration.
Image Description:

The hypothalamus releases gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH), corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH), and thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH) into the portal vessels of the pituitary stalk, through which they reach the anterior pituitary gland. These hypothalamic hormones then directly influence the release of tropic hormones from the anterior pituitary gland into the peripheral bloodstream. GnRH stimulates the release of both luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), CRH stimulates adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), and TRH stimulates thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH).

LH and FSH act on the ovaries/testes to produce sex hormones (estrogen, progesterone, and testosterone); ACTH stimulates the adrenal gland to produce glucocorticoids (primarily cortisol); and TSH stimulates the thyroid gland to produce thyroid hormones (T3 and T4).

The hypothalamus also influences the release of nontropic hormones like prolactin and growth hormone (GH) from the anterior pituitary gland. Prolactin regulates lactation in the mammary glands; GH is stimulated by growth hormone-releasing hormone (GHRH) and in turn stimulates the production of insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1) in the liver.

Hormone secretion is regulated by feedback loops, where the hormones produced by target organs can inhibit the release of their controlling hormones from the hypothalamus and pituitary.

B) INCORRECT:

Somatotropin (growth hormone) is produced and released by the somatotropic cells of the anterior pituitary under the influence of GHRH, which reaches the pituitary gland via the hypophyseal portal system. The serum concentration of somatotropin can be increased in gigantism, which is most often caused by a growth hormone-secreting pituitary adenoma, which can cause a headache. A pituitary adenoma would, however, arise within the sella turcica unlike the suprasellar mass in this patient. Moreover, children with gigantism typically present with tall stature and obesity; this child's height and weight percentiles are within normal limits. Compression of the pituitary stalk, as seen here, would typically result in a decrease in GH secretion as a result of interruption of the hypophyseal portal system.
Image Description:

Hypothalamic hormone GHRH (growth hormone-releasing hormone) stimulates the release of growth hormone (GH) from the acidophilic cells of the pituitary gland. GH-release is inhibited by somatostatin (growth hormone-inhibiting hormone, GHIH), which is produced in the hypothalamus and D cells (pancreas, duodenum). Ghrelin (produced in stomach) acts as another stimulator of GH-release.

As a nontropic hormone, GH either directly stimulates target cells or acts indirectly via synthesis of insulin-like growth factors (IGFs). GH-release is inhibited by GH itself and IGFs, GHRH-release only by IGFs.

C) CORRECT:

The infundibulum is the connection between the hypothalamus and the pituitary gland. Compression of this connection decreases the amount of dopamine delivery from the hypothalamus to the anterior pituitary gland. Dopamine normally inhibits the secretion of prolactin by the lactotroph cells. The loss of inhibition on lactotroph cells results in increased secretion of prolactin hormone (disconnection hyperprolactinemia). Increased prolactin levels would also decrease the levels of gonadotrophins (e.g., LH, FSH) by inhibiting GnRH release.
Image Description:

The nontropic releasing hormones are released in the hypothalamus (A) to the portal vascular system of the anterior pituitary gland (adenohypophysis , 2), where the nontropic hormones growth hormone (GH), melanocyte-stimulating hormone (MSH), and prolactin are released (2). These trigger the secretion of hormones in the target organs: GH leads to the secretion of insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) in the liver, which has an anabolic effect on the muscles and bones (3). In the skin, MSH stimulates the production of melanocytes (4). Prolactin triggers growth and lactation in the mammary glands (5). The inhibiting hormones are also released in the hypothalamus and subsequently reach the anterior pituitary gland, where they inhibit the release of nontropic hormones.

(GHRH = growth hormone-releasing hormone, TRH = thyrotropin-releasing hormone, MSH-RH = melanocyte-stimulating hormone-releasing hormone, MSH-IH = melanocyte-stimulating hormone-inhibiting hormone, Dop = dopamine)

D) INCORRECT:

The adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) is produced by the adrenocorticotropic cells of the anterior pituitary, under the influence of corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH), which reaches the pituitary gland via the hypophyseal portal system. The levels of ACTH would be increased in patients with an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma (Cushing disease), which can cause a headache. A pituitary adenoma would, however, arise within the sella turcica unlike the suprasellar mass in this patient. Moreover, children with Cushing disease typically present with features of secondary hypercortisolism such as central obesity, moon-like faces, proximal muscle atrophy, striae, and hyperpigmentation, which have not been reported in this patient. Compression of the pituitary stalk, as seen here, would typically result in a decrease in ACTH secretion as a result of interruption of the hypophyseal portal system.
Image Description:

The hypothalamus releases gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH), corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH), and thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH) into the portal vessels of the pituitary stalk, through which they reach the anterior pituitary gland. These hypothalamic hormones then directly influence the release of tropic hormones from the anterior pituitary gland into the peripheral bloodstream. GnRH stimulates the release of both luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), CRH stimulates adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), and TRH stimulates thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH).

LH and FSH act on the ovaries/testes to produce sex hormones (estrogen, progesterone, and testosterone); ACTH stimulates the adrenal gland to produce glucocorticoids (primarily cortisol); and TSH stimulates the thyroid gland to produce thyroid hormones (T3 and T4).

The hypothalamus also influences the release of nontropic hormones like prolactin and growth hormone (GH) from the anterior pituitary gland. Prolactin regulates lactation in the mammary glands; GH is stimulated by growth hormone-releasing hormone (GHRH) and in turn stimulates the production of insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1) in the liver.

Hormone secretion is regulated by feedback loops, where the hormones produced by target organs can inhibit the release of their controlling hormones from the hypothalamus and pituitary.

E) INCORRECT:

Vasopressin (antidiuretic hormone) is synthesized in the hypothalamus and sent directly to the posterior pituitary gland via neurophysins for storage and release. Any compression of the pituitary stalk is likely to narrow this connection and result in a reduced amount of stored vasopressin in the posterior pituitary. This patient's suprasellar mass with compression of the pituitary stalk is more likely to result in a decreased amount of released vasopressin.
Image Description:

(1) Antidiuretic hormone (ADH) and oxytocin are synthesized in the nuclei of the hypothalamus.
(2) Both hormones are transported to the posterior pituitary gland (neurohypophysis) via the hypothalamic nerve cell axons and released in the blood.
(3, 4) Oxytocin induces uterine contractions, ADH promotes water reabsorption in the collecting tubules of the kidney
questions.hint: This 8-year old patient with a history of headaches and a CT-scan finding of a suprasellar cystic mass is most likely presenting with a craniopharyngioma. Any suprasellar lesion, including craniopharyngiomas, can compress the pituitary (infundibular) stalk, which can impede communication between the hypothalamus and the pituitary gland.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of increasingly frequent episodes of vertigo and feeling unsteady while walking. She reports that she has had episodic tinnitus in her right ear for the past 3 years. Neurologic examination shows hearing loss in the right ear. An MRI of the brain is shown. Pathologic examination of this patient's lesion is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Whorls of densely packed cells with areas of lamellated calcification
Small blue cells arranged in rosettes around a central neuropil
Hypercellular areas of spindle cells and hypocellular areas of myxoid stroma
Closely packed capillaries and stromal cells filled with lipid vacuoles
Pleomorphic cells clustered around necrotic areas forming pseudopalisades
Cells with clear cytoplasm and central round nucleus resembling a fried egg

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Whorls of densely packed cells with areas of lamellated calcification (psammoma bodies) suggest a meningioma, which arises from arachnoid cap cells. Symptoms depend on the location of the meningioma, and patients are often asymptomatic if the tumor is small. On MRI, meningiomas appear as round, sharply demarcated, space-occupying lesions, which is similar to this patient's tumor. In rare cases, meningiomas arise at the cerebellopontine angle. This can manifest with hearing loss and ataxia, but usually does not cause tinnitus. Furthermore, because vestibular schwannomas account for > 80% of tumors of the cerebellopontine angle, this diagnosis is much more likely.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of tissue biopsied from a brain tumor (H&E stain)

Several eosinophilic cells arranged in whorls are visible. The whorls have a layered or lamellated appearance, resembling the layers of an onion. These are known as meningocytic whorls. Two of these whorls have a deeply basophilic acellular core, known as a psammoma body, which indicates dystrophic calcification.

Meningocytic (onion skin) whorls and psammoma bodies are typically seen in meningiomas.

B) INCORRECT:

Small blue cells arranged in rosettes around a central neuropil, known as Homer-Wright rosettes, suggest medulloblastoma. Medulloblastomas can cause gait abnormalities and manifest as unsteadiness while walking, but tinnitus and hearing loss would be uncommon. Furthermore, these tumors are the most common neurological malignancy in childhood and would, therefore, be unlikely in a 40-year-old patient. Moreover, they typically arise in the cerebellum, not the cerebellopontine angle.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of cerebellar vermis tissue (H&E stain)

Densely packed, small, blue anaplastic cells are present throughout the specimen. The cells have pleomorphic and hyperchromatic nuclei.
On the right, a vessel (its lumen mostly obstructed by eosinophilic material) can be seen.

These are typical histopathological findings of medulloblastoma.

C) CORRECT:

Hypercellular areas of spindle cells and hypocellular areas of myxoid stroma are characteristic findings of vestibular schwannoma, a tumor arising from the Schwann cells of the vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII).
