Schwann cells are of neural crest origin, which explains why vestibular schwannomas stain positive for S100.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a tumor arising from the vestibular portion of cranial nerve VIII (H&E stain; medium magnification)

A characteristic finding of neuromas is the simultaneous occurrence of areas with densely packed nuclei (palisade pattern; A) and scattered or anuclear areas (B). There is also a large number of vacuolated cells (C).

D) INCORRECT:

Closely packed capillaries and stromal cells filled with lipid vacuoles suggest hemangioblastoma, a tumor of blood vessels that is often associated with von Hippel-Lindau disease. Patients with hemangioblastoma can have cerebellar signs such as ataxia, which can manifest as unsteadiness while walking, but tinnitus and hearing loss would be uncommon. Moreover, hemangioblastomas typically occur in the cerebellum, brainstem, or spinal cord and are unlikely to be found in the cerebellopontine angle.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a biopsy from a cerebellar mass (H&E stain; high magnification)

Numerous thin-walled small blood vessels (examples indicated by yellow overlay) containing red stained erythrocytes are visible throughout the tumor.
Surrounding the blood vessels large stromal cells (examples indicated by blue overlay) with pale intracytoplasmic lipid inclusions (so-called "foamy" cytoplasm) can be seen.

This appearance is indicative of hemangioblastoma. The diagnosis was confirmed by immunohistochemistry.

E) INCORRECT:

Pleomorphic cells clustered around necrotic areas to form pseudopalisades suggest glioblastoma multiforme (GM), a malignant tumor of astrocytes. Depending on the location, GM can manifest with focal neurologic deficits and seizures. Tinnitus and hearing loss would be uncommon. However, GM typically involves the cerebral hemispheres, sometimes crossing the midline to form a “butterfly glioma.” Furthermore, MRI typically shows an irregular lesion with central heterogeneity that corresponds to the central necrosis, which is not consistent with this patient's imaging.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a cerebral tissue specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)

A high number and density of highly pleomorphic cells with hyperchromatic and irregular nuclei are visible (examples indicated by arrowheads. These cells are aggregated around the periphery of the necrotic zone (green overlay), forming a nuclear pseudopalisading architecture.

These are the characteristic features of glioblastoma multiforme.

F) INCORRECT:

Cells with clear cytoplasm and a central round nucleus resembling a fried egg suggest oligodendroglioma. Patients can present with sensory deficits and epileptic seizures. Vertigo, tinnitus, and hearing loss, however, would not be expected. While oligodendrogliomas most commonly occur in the frontal and temporal lobes, this patient's tumor is located in the cerebellopontine angle, which is more suggestive of vestibular schwannoma.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of brain tissue (H&E stain; very high magnification)

Monomorphic cells with enlarged, round/oval nuclei surrounded by a clear halo of unstained cytoplasm, which is an artifact of processing, are visible (green overlay). Thin blood vessels with an interlacing pattern are also visible (yellow overlay).

These are the typical features of oligodendroglioma.
questions.hint: This patient presents with symptoms of vestibulocochlear nerve dysfunction (imbalance, vertigo, tinnitus, hearing loss). The MRI shows a hyperintense lesion in the right cerebellopontine angle, which is consistent with a vestibular schwannoma.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy undergoes resection of a primary brain tumor. Microscopic examination of the resected specimen shows calcifications and cystic areas filled with cholesterol crystals. This tumor was most likely located in which of the following labeled areas in the schematic overview of the brain?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Glioblastomas are highly malignant brain tumors located in the white matter of the cerebral hemispheres. In addition to being a very rare tumor in childhood, the calcifications and cholesterol crystals found in this patient's histopathologic examination are inconsistent with glioblastoma. Instead, this kind of tumor is characterized by multifocal areas of necrotic and hemorrhagic lesions.

B) INCORRECT:

The frontal lobe is the most common location of oligodendrogliomas. They are notable for their “honeycomb” or “fried egg” histopathological appearance, which is due to the presence of calcification, cysts and necrotic areas. Oligodendrogliomas have a peak incidence between 40–50 years of age and are uncommon in children.

C) CORRECT:

Craniopharyngiomas are relatively benign tumors that are located above the sella turcica but may also expand into the sella. They arise from the remnants of Rathke pouch near the pituitary stalk. Craniopharyngiomas are the most common cause of hypopituitarism in children and have a bimodal age distribution with peaks at 5–14 years and 50–75 years of age.

D) INCORRECT:

Pinealomas are expected to arise from this region, which represents the pineal gland. The most common pinealoma in children is a germinoma, which would show undifferentiated germ cells on histology. Calcifications and cystic areas filled with cholesterol crystals, as seen in this patient, would not be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

The cerebellum is a frequent location of pilocytic astrocytomas, the most common benign brain tumor in children. Histopathology would show microcysts, Rosenthal fibers, and GFAP positive staining, none of which are seen in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

The anterior cerebellum is a common location of medulloblastomas, the most prevalent malignant brain tumor in childhood. Histopathologic examination typically shows rosette-shaped small tumor cells (Homer-Wright rosettes). However, calcifications and cystic areas filled with cholesterol crystals as seen in this patient would not be expected. Medulloblastomas often extend into the 4th ventricle.

G) INCORRECT:

Ependymomas typically arise from the floor of the 4th ventricle. Although calcifications and cystic areas may be present in biopsy, histopathologic examination would also show characteristic ependymal rosettes with perivascular pseudorosettes. Moreover, cholesterol crystals would not be expected in ependymomas.
questions.hint: Calcifications and cholesterol crystals are typical histopathologic features of craniopharyngiomas.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 4-month history of worsening dizziness, nausea, and feeling clumsy. An MRI of the brain shows a well-demarcated, 4-cm cystic mass in the posterior fossa. The patient undergoes complete surgical resection of the mass. Pathologic examination of the surgical specimen shows parallel bundles of cells with eosinophilic, corkscrew-like processes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Medulloblastoma, the most common malignant primary brain tumor of childhood, can also cause dizziness, nausea, and clumsiness (due to hydrocephalus and/or cerebellar damage) and appear as a well-defined cerebellar mass with cysts on imaging, as well. However, it is characterized histologically by the presence of small, round, undifferentiated basophilic cells (primitive neuroectoderm cells) and Homer-Wright rosettes.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of cerebellar vermis tissue (H&E stain)

Densely packed, small, blue anaplastic cells are present throughout the specimen. The cells have pleomorphic and hyperchromatic nuclei.
On the right, a vessel (its lumen mostly obstructed by eosinophilic material) can be seen.

These are typical histopathological findings of medulloblastoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Ependymomas typically occur in the posterior fossa (floor of the fourth ventricle) and can also present with dizziness, nausea, and clumsiness, due to obstructive hydrocephalus. However, they are characterized histologically by the presence of perivascular pseudorosettes and basal ciliary bodies (blepharoplasts) and are more common in early childhood.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a brain tumor tissue specimen (H&E stain; low magnification)

There is an abnormally high number of cells with round nuclei and abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm. Some cells are arranged in a spoke-and-wheel pattern, surrounding an empty central space. Such patterns are called ependymal rosettes (example indicated by green overlay). Other cells are arranged concentrically around blood vessels, producing a similar appearance (perivascular pseudorosettes; example indicated yellow overlay).

These are typical histopathological features of ependymoma.

C) CORRECT:

Pilocytic astrocytoma is the most common pediatric primary brain tumor. It typically occurs in the cerebellum (posterior cranial fossa), but can also occur in supratentorial regions such as the optic nerve (optic glioma) and the cerebral hemispheres. Tumors in the posterior cranial fossa can present with dizziness, nausea, and clumsiness due to obstructive hydrocephalus and/or cerebellar damage. On imaging, a pilocytic astrocytoma typically appears as a well-demarcated cystic mass with a brightly enhancing nodule in the wall of the cyst.

Optic gliomas, a type of pilocytic astrocytoma in the optic pathway, are strongly associated with neurofibromatosis type 1. A subependymal giant cell astrocytoma, another low-grade astrocytoma that occurs within ventricles, is associated with tuberous sclerosis.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a tissue section of a brain mass (H&E stain; high magnification)

There is an abundance of eosinophilic, fusiform inclusions (Rosenthal fibers; examples indicated by blue overlay).

Rosenthal fibers are intracellular inclusions within astrocyte cytoplasmic processes. They represent a nonspecific degenerative changes that are often found in CNS tumors (in this case in pilocytic astrocytoma).

D) INCORRECT:

Craniopharyngiomas are the most common supratentorial tumors in pediatric patients; they are typically in the suprasellar region and cause bitemporal hemianopsia or endocrine abnormalities (e.g., hyperprolactinemia, hypopituitarism). Dizziness, nausea, and clumsiness would not be expected. The adamantinomatous variant of this tumor is characterized histologically by the presence of cholesterol crystals, calcification, and nests of “wet keratin” (desquamated cells) surrounded by stratified odontogenic epithelium, while the papillary variant is characterized by metaplastic squamous cells with very few or absent calcifications and cysts.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a brain tissue sample (HPS stain; intermediate magnification)

Trabeculae and nests of squamous epithelium (examples indicated by yellow overlay) with palisading cells (examples indicated by blue hatched overlay) are visible.
Additionally, there are multiple cysts (examples indicated by yellow hatched overlay), nodules of anuclear ghost cells (examples indicated by blue overlay) containing wet keratin, and calcifications (examples indicated by blue outline) .

This is the typical histological appearance of an adamantinomatous craniopharyngioma.

E) INCORRECT:

A hemangioblastoma typically occurs in the posterior cranial fossa (cerebellum). It manifests with dizziness, nausea, and clumsiness (due to hydrocephalus and/or cerebellar damage) and appears as a well-demarcated cystic mass on imaging. However, hemangioblastomas are vascular tumors characterized histologically by closely packed, thin-walled vessels with minimal intervening brain parenchyma, and they are extremely rare among children. They typically occur among middle-aged adults.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a biopsy from a cerebellar mass (H&E stain; high magnification)

Numerous thin-walled small blood vessels (examples indicated by yellow overlay) containing red stained erythrocytes are visible throughout the tumor.
Surrounding the blood vessels large stromal cells (examples indicated by blue overlay) with pale intracytoplasmic lipid inclusions (so-called "foamy" cytoplasm) can be seen.

This appearance is indicative of hemangioblastoma. The diagnosis was confirmed by immunohistochemistry.

F) INCORRECT:

A pinealoma typically occurs in the posterior fossa (dorsal midbrain) and can manifest with features of hydrocephalus (e.g., dizziness, nausea, and clumsiness) during childhood. However, most childhood pinealomas are germinomas characterized histologically by a lymphoid stroma and large vacuolated cells with enlarged oval nuclei. Moreover, other features associated with pinealomas, such as Parinaud syndrome (vertical gaze palsy, lid retraction, nystagmus, light-near dissociation) and precocious puberty, are absent in this patient.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a pineal tumor biopsy sample (H&E stain; high magnification)

Large tumor cells with abundant pale cytoplasm and pleomorphic nuclei can be seen (examples marked by green overlay). Additionally, the tumor tissue contains numerous intermixed lymphocytes (comparatively small cells with round dark nuclei).

These histopathological findings are consistent with a pineal germinoma, which was confirmed by immunohistochemistry; ovarian dysgerminomas and testicular seminomas have a very similar appearance.
questions.hint: The eosinophilic, corkscrew-like processes seen in this patient's biopsy are Rosenthal fibers. The cells from this brain tumor are glial in origin and will stain positive for glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP).

questions.text: An otherwise healthy 49-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of worsening headaches and increasing irritability. Examination shows bilateral papilledema. An MRI of the brain shows a mass in the right temporal lobe with heterogeneous peripheral rim enhancement that crosses the midline. He undergoes surgical resection of the mass. Gross examination shows a poorly-demarcated mass with areas of hemorrhage and necrosis. Microscopic examination of the mass will most likely show which of the following?

choices.text: Spindle cells with hypercellular and hypocellular regions
Closely-packed capillaries and foamy stromal cells
Cells with clear cytoplasm and central round nuclei
Small blue cells arranged in rosettes

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Spindle cells with hypercellular and hypocellular regions are characteristic of schwannomas. Schwannomas typically occur at the cerebellopontine angle and present with lateralized symptoms, especially vestibulocochlear nerve dysfunction, whereas headache, irritability, and papilledema are unlikely findings. Moreover, hemorrhage or necrosis are uncommon, as schwannomas are slow-growing tumors.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a tumor arising from the vestibular portion of cranial nerve VIII (H&E stain; medium magnification)

A characteristic finding of neuromas is the simultaneous occurrence of areas with densely packed nuclei (palisade pattern; A) and scattered or anuclear areas (B). There is also a large number of vacuolated cells (C).

B) INCORRECT:

Closely-packed capillaries and foamy stromal cells are characteristic of hemangioblastomas, highly vascularized benign tumors most likely to be found in the cerebellum. They may present in middle age with papilledema, but patients would likely show cerebellar symptoms or polycythemia (due to production of erythropoietin). Headache and irritability as well as findings of hemorrhage and necrosis would be unlikely in a hemangioblastoma.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a cerebellar tissue specimen (HPS stain; high magnification)

Numerous polygonal neoplastic stromal cells with lipid-laden vacuoles (examples indicated by arrowheads) can be seen, resulting in the typical clear-cell appearance. Additionally, there is an abundance of small, thin-walled blood vessels, many of which are densely packed together (examples indicated by blue overlay).

C) CORRECT:

Pleomorphic cells arranged in pseudopalisades are a hallmark of glioblastoma multiforme, a highly malignant brain tumor that arises from astrocytes. Pseudopalisades are arrays of tumor cells migrating away from an area of central necrosis. Histological findings in glioblastoma multiforme vary greatly but would most likely also show microvascular proliferation as well as necrosis and hemorrhage (as already seen on gross examination).
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a cerebral tissue specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)

A high number and density of highly pleomorphic cells with hyperchromatic and irregular nuclei are visible (examples indicated by arrowheads. These cells are aggregated around the periphery of the necrotic zone (green overlay), forming a nuclear pseudopalisading architecture.

These are the characteristic features of glioblastoma multiforme.

D) INCORRECT:

Cells with clear cytoplasm and central round nuclei (fried egg appearance) are characteristics of oligodendrogliomas. Oligodendrogliomas would not be expected to present with bilateral papilledema but rather with seizures and sensory deficits. They are slow-growing tumors that usually occur in the frontal lobe and manifest as well-defined gray masses with areas of calcification; necrosis would not be expected.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of brain tissue (H&E stain; very high magnification)

Monomorphic cells with enlarged, round/oval nuclei surrounded by a clear halo of unstained cytoplasm, which is an artifact of processing, are visible (green overlay). Thin blood vessels with an interlacing pattern are also visible (yellow overlay).

These are the typical features of oligodendroglioma.

E) INCORRECT:

Small blue cells arranged in rosettes (Homer-Wright rosettes) are characteristic of medulloblastomas. Medulloblastomas originate from the primitive neuroectoderm and are the most common malignant brain tumor in children (peak incidence 3–5 years). Medulloblastomas are typically found in the cerebellum, often compress the 4th ventricle, and manifests with hydrocephalus and posterior vermis syndrome. On MRI they show a diffuse enhancement. The location, clinical presentation, and imaging findings of this adult patient's tumor are not consistent with medulloblastoma.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of cerebellar vermis tissue (H&E stain)

Densely packed, small, blue anaplastic cells are present throughout the specimen. The cells have pleomorphic and hyperchromatic nuclei.
On the right, a vessel (its lumen mostly obstructed by eosinophilic material) can be seen.

These are typical histopathological findings of medulloblastoma.

F) INCORRECT:

Areas of lamellated calcification are consistent with psammoma bodies, which are characteristic of meningioma and other noncerebral tumors. Meningiomas are composed of spindle cells arranged in a whorled pattern. While they might also show rim enhancement on MRI, as seen in this patient, meningiomas usually appear as a homogeneous, well-defined lesion outside the brain without areas of hemorrhage and necrosis.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of tissue biopsied from a brain tumor (HPS stain)

Several eosinophilic cells are visible, arranged in whorls (purple overlay) and sheets. A mass of disorganized cells is visible in the top right corner (yellow overlay). The nuclei of these cells show features of malignancy (i.e., large size or high N:C ratio, nuclear pleomorphism, prominent nucleoli, and mitotic figures). The intervening stroma contains numerous blood vessels (green overlay).

Hypercellularity, whorled or sheet-like architecture, and hypervascularity are typical features of a meningioma. Psammoma bodies (not seen here) are another characteristic feature of meningioma and would appear as basophilic whorls.
questions.hint: A brain tumor in the temporal lobe that crosses the midline and displays irregular rim enhancement is suggestive of glioblastoma, the most common type of malignant brain tumor in adults. The gross pathology findings of a poorly-demarcated mass with areas of hemorrhage and necrosis are consistent with this diagnosis.

questions.text: A previously healthy 4-year-old girl is brought to the physician for evaluation of a 3-week history of recurrent vomiting and difficulty walking. Examination shows a broad-based gait and bilateral optic disc swelling. An MRI shows an intracranial tumor. A ventriculoperitoneal shunt is placed, and surgical excision of the tumor is performed. A photomicrograph of a section of the tumor is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Glioblastoma multiforme, which predominantly develops in adults, most commonly arises in the cerebral hemispheres (supratentorial region). Biopsy of this tumor shows pleomorphic cells with hyperchromatic and irregular nuclei that aggregate around a necrotic center (pseudopalisading necrosis), not the histopathologic findings seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a cerebral tissue specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)

A high number and density of highly pleomorphic cells with hyperchromatic and irregular nuclei are visible (examples indicated by arrowheads. These cells are aggregated around the periphery of the necrotic zone (green overlay), forming a nuclear pseudopalisading architecture.

These are the characteristic features of glioblastoma multiforme.

B) INCORRECT:

Intracranial ependymoma, which predominantly develops in children, most commonly arises in the fourth ventricle and can cause symptoms of increased intracranial pressure. However, biopsy of this tumor shows cells with abundant cytoplasm arranged around a central vascular core (perivascular pseudorosettes), not the histopathologic findings seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a brain tumor tissue specimen (H&E stain; low magnification)

There is an abnormally high number of cells with round nuclei and abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm. Some cells are arranged in a spoke-and-wheel pattern, surrounding an empty central space. Such patterns are called ependymal rosettes (example indicated by green overlay). Other cells are arranged concentrically around blood vessels, producing a similar appearance (perivascular pseudorosettes; example indicated yellow overlay).

These are typical histopathological features of ependymoma.

C) CORRECT:

Medulloblastoma is the most common primary malignant brain tumor of childhood and has a peak incidence between 3–5 years of age. This tumor typically develops in the cerebellum. Destruction of the cerebellar vermis causes truncal ataxia, and compression of the fourth ventricle by the tumor causes noncommunicating hydrocephalus and symptoms of increased intracranial pressure as seen in this patient. The main histopathologic feature of medulloblastoma is the presence of small round blue cells (primitive neuroectoderm cells) that surround a central, fibril-rich neuropil (Homer Wright rosettes).
Image Description:

Cranial MRI (T1-weighted, with contrast)

There is a mass in the posterior cranial fossa. It features solid parts (green overlay) and cystic parts (red overlay).

Location and appearance are typical of a medulloblastoma.

(D: diencephalon; P: pons; C: cerebellum; yellow outline: cerebellar tentorium)

D) INCORRECT:

Oligodendroglioma, which predominantly develops in adults, most commonly arises in the frontal lobe (supratentorial region). Biopsy of this tumor shows round cells with clear cytoplasm (fried-egg cells) and a chicken-wire pattern formed by anastomosing capillaries, not the histopathologic findings seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of brain tissue (H&E stain; very high magnification)

Monomorphic cells with enlarged, round/oval nuclei surrounded by a clear halo of unstained cytoplasm, which is an artifact of processing, are visible (green overlay). Thin blood vessels with an interlacing pattern are also visible (yellow overlay).

These are the typical features of oligodendroglioma.

E) INCORRECT:

Pinealoma, which predominantly develops in children, typically arises near the tectum of the midbrain and can cause symptoms of increased intracranial pressure due to compression of the cerebral aqueduct. However, most pediatric pinealomas are germinomas characterized histologically by a lymphoid stroma and large, vacuolated cells with enlarged oval nuclei, not the histopathologic findings seen in this patient. Moreover, this patient does not have other manifestations associated with pinealomas such as Parinaud syndrome and precocious puberty.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a pineal tumor biopsy sample (H&E stain; high magnification)

Large tumor cells with abundant pale cytoplasm and pleomorphic nuclei can be seen (examples marked by green overlay). Additionally, the tumor tissue contains numerous intermixed lymphocytes (comparatively small cells with round dark nuclei).

These histopathological findings are consistent with a pineal germinoma, which was confirmed by immunohistochemistry; ovarian dysgerminomas and testicular seminomas have a very similar appearance.

F) INCORRECT:

Pilocytic astrocytoma, which is the most common pediatric primary brain tumor, typically arises in the cerebellum and can cause symptoms of increased intracranial pressure and truncal ataxia. However, biopsy of this tumor shows cells with eosinophilic, corkscrew-like processes (Rosenthal fibers), not the histopathologic findings seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a tissue section of a brain mass (H&E stain; high magnification)

There is an abundance of eosinophilic, fusiform inclusions (Rosenthal fibers; examples indicated by blue overlay).

Rosenthal fibers are intracellular inclusions within astrocyte cytoplasmic processes. They represent a nonspecific degenerative changes that are often found in CNS tumors (in this case in pilocytic astrocytoma).

G) INCORRECT:

Hemangioblastoma, which predominantly develops in adults, typically arises in the cerebellum and can cause symptoms of increased intracranial pressure and truncal ataxia. Biopsy of this tumor shows closely packed, thin-walled vessels with minimal intervening brain parenchyma, not the histopathologic findings seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a biopsy from a cerebellar mass (H&E stain; high magnification)

Numerous thin-walled small blood vessels (examples indicated by yellow overlay) containing red stained erythrocytes are visible throughout the tumor.
Surrounding the blood vessels large stromal cells (examples indicated by blue overlay) with pale intracytoplasmic lipid inclusions (so-called "foamy" cytoplasm) can be seen.

This appearance is indicative of hemangioblastoma. The diagnosis was confirmed by immunohistochemistry.
questions.hint: The photomicrograph shows Homer Wright rosettes, which consist of differentiated tumor cells around a central region of nerve fibers.

questions.text:
The response options for the next 2 items are the same. Select one answer for each item in the set.
For each patient with a brain tumor, select the most likely diagnosis.
A 10-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of headaches and vomiting over the past week. He also has a 2-day history of blurry vision. His uncle died from colorectal cancer, and his older brother has multiple colonic polyps. The patient is alert and oriented. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 84/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows weakness of the lower extremities and a broad-based gait. An MRI of the brain shows mild hydrocephalus and a contrast-enhancing intraparenchymal mass in the cerebellar vermis.
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anaplastic astrocytomas are rare, malignant brain tumors that can cause headaches, nausea, and focal neurologic deficits. However, these tumors most commonly develop in adults (usually between 30–40 years of age), not in children. In addition, though they can appear on MRI as contrast-enhancing masses, they rarely cause hydrocephalus because they are typically located in the cerebral hemispheres, not the cerebellar vermis.
Image Description:

MRI head (top left: T1-weighted, axial plane; top right: T2-weighted, axial plane; bottom left: T1-weighted, with contrast, axial plane; bottom right: T1-weighted, with contrast, coronal plane)

There is a large, well-defined mass in the right frontal lobe (green overlay), which demonstrates hypointense signal on the T1-weighted images and hyperintense signal on T2-weighting with no significant surrounding edema. No significant enhancement is demonstrated on the post-contrast sequences.

B) INCORRECT:

Oligodendrogliomas are slow-growing tumors that can cause headaches, nausea, and focal neurologic deficits. However, these tumors most commonly develop in adults (usually between 40–50 years of age), not in children. In addition, they typically appear on MRI as T2-hyperintense lesions in the cerebral hemispheres that show areas of calcification, not contrast-enhancing intraparenchymal masses in the cerebellar vermis.
Image Description:

Cranial CT scan (axial view)

A large hypodense lesion (green overlay) with multiple intralesional hyperdense calcifications (yellow overlay) is visible in the temporal lobe.

C) INCORRECT:

Hemangioblastomas are rare, benign, slow-growing, highly-vascularized tumors that can cause headaches and nausea. However, these tumors most commonly develop in adults (usually between 20–50 years of age), not in children. In addition, they typically appear on MRI as T2-hyperintense, nodular lesions with cystic components in the cerebellum or brainstem, not contrast-enhancing intraparenchymal masses in the cerebellar vermis.
Image Description:

MRI head (with contrast; axial view)

A brightly enhancing, sharply delimited nodular mass (white arrow) with nonenhancing, cystic areas is visible within the right cerebellar hemisphere.

These findings are consistent with cerebellar hemangioblastoma.

D) CORRECT:

Medulloblastomas are the most common malignant brain tumors in children (peak incidence at 3–5 years of age). These tumors often develop near the cerebellar midline and can, therefore, cause manifestations of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., headache, nausea, papilledema). Treatment usually consists of resection and chemotherapy (combined with radiotherapy in children ≥ 3 years of age). This patient's family history is suggestive of a diagnosis of Turcot syndrome, a rare inherited disorder characterized by the combination of primary brain tumors and colorectal cancer or polyposis.
Image Description:

MRI Head (T2-weighted; axial view) of a 7-year-old boy

There is a lobulated heterogeneous posterior fossa mass (green overlay) present in the midline of the cerebellum at the level of the fourth ventricle. The fourth ventricle is obscured by the mass and is, therefore, not well seen in this image.

This is a medulloblastoma, the most common malignant pediatric tumor of the central nervous system. Medulloblastomas most commonly involve the cerebellar vermis, the structure that connects the two cerebellar hemispheres. In the pediatric population, other tumors that commonly occur in similar locations include brainstem glioma, ependymoma, choroid plexus papilloma, atypical teratoid/rhabdoid tumor, and astrocytoma. All of these should be considered in this case, although a brainstem glioma would rather be located predominantly within the brainstem rather than the vermis and is, therefore, less likely.

Arrowhead: basilar artery; C: cerebellum

E) INCORRECT:

Ependymomas of the brain are benign tumors that most commonly occur in early childhood and can cause hydrocephalus. However, they typically develop in the 4th ventricle, rather than in the cerebellar vermis. In addition, ependymomas can vary in appearance on MRI but often show necrosis, cystic changes, hemorrhage, and calcifications.
Image Description:

MRI brain (FLAIR; sagittal view)

A well-defined heterogeneous hyperintense lesion is visible within the expanded 4th ventricle (green overlay). At the superior aspect of the lesion, multiple dark foci are present (arrowheads), representing cysts. They appear dark in this image as the fluid signal is removed on FLAIR sequences. This lesion has obstructed circulation of the cerebrospinal fluid, resulting in ventriculomegaly (indicated by dashed line).

Ependymomas commonly arise within the fourth ventricle. They are usually hyperintense on T2 weighted/FLAIR images and can demonstrate cystic change, such as in this case, as well as hemorrhage.

F) INCORRECT:

Schwannomas are slow-growing tumors that can cause headaches and nausea. However, these tumors are most commonly located near the cerebellopontine angle, not in the cerebellar vermis. In addition, these tumors often cause tinnitus, hearing loss, dizziness, and/or disequilibrium from cranial nerve VIII compression. Moreover, the median age of patients with schwannoma is 50 years; it is very uncommon in children.
Image Description:

Acoustic neuromas are benign tumors that arise from Schwann cells and primarily originate within the vestibular portion of cranial nerve VIII. The tumor originates within the internal acoustic canal with variable extension into the cerebellopontine angle. Early symptoms occur due to pressure on the cochlear nerve (unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus) and vestibular nerve (dizziness, unsteady gait, disequilibrium). If the tumor further expands into the cerebellopontine angle, further symptoms arise due to compression of CN V (paresthesia, hypoesthesia, unilateral facial pain), CN VII (unilateral facial weakness), and the cerebellum (ataxia).

G) INCORRECT:

Glioblastoma multiforme is a very aggressive tumor that can cause headaches and nausea. However, these tumors most commonly develop in adults (usually between 65–75 years of age), not in children. In addition, they typically appear on MRI as ring-enhancing masses in the cerebral hemispheres (potentially crossing the midline), not in the cerebellar vermis.
Image Description:

T1-weighted contrast-enhanced MRI, frontal view: bihemisphere garland-like contrast enhancement. There is peripheral contrast agent enhancement (blue overlay) with central necrosis (green overlay). The third ventricle (arrowhead) is centrally located. The tumor is displacing the posterior horn of the lateral ventricle (red overlay). Diagnosis: bilateral glioblastoma (butterfly glioma).

H) INCORRECT:

Meningiomas are slow-growing tumors that can cause headaches and nausea. Though these tumors are the most common primary central nervous system tumors in adults (with a peak incidence in the sixth decade of life), they are rarely found in children. In addition, because they derive from the dura, they cannot develop in the cerebellar vermis.
Image Description:

MRI head (T1-weighted; with contrast; sagittal plane)

There is a well-circumscribed homogeneous mass (green overlay) along the cerebral convexity. It demonstrates intense, homogeneous enhancement, equivalent to that of adjacent dura mater. Displacement without invasion of the surrounding white matter supports an extra-axial location.

This is a case of meningioma, a dural-based tumor. The dura is represented in this image by the thin, discontinuously enhancing line covering the inner surface of the skull (indicated by arrowhead).

I) INCORRECT:

Craniopharyngiomas are brain tumors that have a bimodal distribution of age (children 5–14 years of age and adults 50–75 years of age). These tumors can cause headaches and nausea due to obstructive hydrocephalus and traction on surrounding structures. They can also cause visual symptoms (typically bitemporal hemianopsia from compression of the optic chiasm). However, craniopharyngiomas often cause other symptoms, including hyperprolactinemia, delayed growth, and central diabetes insipidus (from compression of the anterior or posterior pituitary gland). In addition, they often show calcifications and cysts on MRI.
Image Description:

MRI of the brain (T1-weighted; sagittal view; with contrast)

A hyperintense, ovoid, sharply demarcated lesion (green overlay) is visible within the sella turcica and partially extends into the sphenoidal sinus.

The location and appearance of the lesion suggest a craniopharyngioma or a pituitary adenoma.

J) INCORRECT:

Colorectal cancer that metastasizes to the brain can cause headaches, nausea, and visual deficits. Risk factors for colorectal cancer include a family history of colorectal cancer and polyps, which are suggestive of an inherited cancer syndrome. However, colorectal cancer typically initially manifests with abdominal symptoms (e.g., gastrointestinal bleeding) and only metastasizes late in the disease course. In addition, brain metastases typically manifest on MRI as multiple, circumscribed lesions with perifocal edema, not a single intraparenchymal mass.

K) INCORRECT:

Optic gliomas are low-grade, astrocytic tumors that most commonly occur in early childhood (90% before 10 years of age) and can cause visual impairment and manifestations of increased intracranial pressure. However, they typically develop in the optic nerve and/or chiasm, not in the cerebellar vermis.
Image Description:

MRI head (T2-weighted; axial plane)

There is a large hyperintense mass (green overlay) in the left intraconal space displacing the ocular globe out of the orbital cavity (exophthalmos). The intraconal space is located posterior to the globe and contained within the cone formed by the recti muscles. The mass is well-defined and displaces rather than invades surrounding structures. The left optic nerve is not visualized on this image, and the mass either arises from it or displaces it. The normal-appearing right optic nerve (red overlay) is well visualized.

The differential diagnosis for intraconal masses depends on whether or not the lesion is continuous with the optic nerve. Differential diagnoses for masses involving the optic nerve include, but are not limited to, meningioma, glioma, and lymphoma. Differential diagnoses for masses not involving the nerve include, but are not limited to, hemangioma, schwannoma, and rhabdomyosarcoma.

L) INCORRECT:

Pinealomas are rare brain tumors of childhood that can cause manifestations of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., headache, nausea, papilledema) due to obstructive hydrocephalus. However, these tumors develop in the pineal region, not in the cerebellar vermis, and typically have a cystic appearance on MRI.
questions.hint: This patient most likely has a primitive neuroectodermal tumor.

questions.text:
For each patient with a brain tumor, select the most likely diagnosis.
A 63-year-old man is brought to the emergency room 30 minutes after a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. He has had recurrent headaches for the past 2 months and a 3-year history of progressive hearing difficulties in both ears. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 20 years. He takes flax seeds daily for constipation. He appears drowsy and is oriented to person and place only. His temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 94/min, and blood pressure is 145/88 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a laceration on the tongue. An MRI of the brain shows an infiltrative lesion that expands into both hemispheres with associated irregular rim enhancement, perifocal edema, and central necrosis.
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anaplastic astrocytomas are rare, malignant brain tumors that most commonly develop in adults (usually between 30–40 years of age) and can cause altered mental status, seizures, and headaches. These tumors most commonly develop in the cerebral hemispheres. However, they typically appear on MRI as T2-hyperintense lesions without central necrosis.
Image Description:

MRI head (top left: T1-weighted, axial plane; top right: T2-weighted, axial plane; bottom left: T1-weighted, with contrast, axial plane; bottom right: T1-weighted, with contrast, coronal plane)

There is a large, well-defined mass in the right frontal lobe (green overlay), which demonstrates hypointense signal on the T1-weighted images and hyperintense signal on T2-weighting with no significant surrounding edema. No significant enhancement is demonstrated on the post-contrast sequences.

B) INCORRECT:

Oligodendrogliomas are slow-growing tumors that most commonly develop in adults (usually between 40–50 years of age) and can cause altered mental status, seizures, and headaches. These tumors most commonly develop in the cerebral hemispheres. However, they typically appear on MRI as T2-hyperintense lesions that show areas of calcification.
Image Description:

Cranial CT scan (axial view)

A large hypodense lesion (green overlay) with multiple intralesional hyperdense calcifications (yellow overlay) is visible in the temporal lobe.

C) INCORRECT:

Hemangioblastomas are rare, benign, slow-growing, highly-vascularized tumors that most commonly develop in adults (usually between 20–50 years of age) and can cause altered mental status, seizures, and headaches. However, they typically appear on MRI as T2-hyperintense, nodular lesions with cystic components in the cerebellum or brainstem.
Image Description:

MRI head (with contrast; axial view)

A brightly enhancing, sharply delimited nodular mass (white arrow) with nonenhancing, cystic areas is visible within the right cerebellar hemisphere.

These findings are consistent with cerebellar hemangioblastoma.

D) INCORRECT:

Medulloblastomas can cause altered mental status, seizures, and headaches. However, these tumors are more common in children (peak incidence at 3–5 years of age) and typically develop near the cerebellar midline. In addition, they typically appear on MRI as diffusely-enhancing lesions that can show calcifications.
Image Description:

MRI Head (T2-weighted; axial view) of a 7-year-old boy

There is a lobulated heterogeneous posterior fossa mass (green overlay) present in the midline of the cerebellum at the level of the fourth ventricle. The fourth ventricle is obscured by the mass and is, therefore, not well seen in this image.

This is a medulloblastoma, the most common malignant pediatric tumor of the central nervous system. Medulloblastomas most commonly involve the cerebellar vermis, the structure that connects the two cerebellar hemispheres. In the pediatric population, other tumors that commonly occur in similar locations include brainstem glioma, ependymoma, choroid plexus papilloma, atypical teratoid/rhabdoid tumor, and astrocytoma. All of these should be considered in this case, although a brainstem glioma would rather be located predominantly within the brainstem rather than the vermis and is, therefore, less likely.

Arrowhead: basilar artery; C: cerebellum

E) INCORRECT:

Ependymomas of the brain are benign tumors that can cause altered mental status, seizures, and headaches. However, these tumors are more common in children and typically develop in the 4th ventricle. In addition, though ependymomas can show necrosis on MRI, they typically also have cystic changes, hemorrhage, and calcifications.
Image Description:

MRI brain (FLAIR; sagittal view)

A well-defined heterogeneous hyperintense lesion is visible within the expanded 4th ventricle (green overlay). At the superior aspect of the lesion, multiple dark foci are present (arrowheads), representing cysts. They appear dark in this image as the fluid signal is removed on FLAIR sequences. This lesion has obstructed circulation of the cerebrospinal fluid, resulting in ventriculomegaly (indicated by dashed line).

Ependymomas commonly arise within the fourth ventricle. They are usually hyperintense on T2 weighted/FLAIR images and can demonstrate cystic change, such as in this case, as well as hemorrhage.

F) INCORRECT:

Schwannomas are slow-growing tumors that most commonly affect adults (median age of 50 years) and can cause altered mental status, headaches, and hearing loss. However, hearing loss associated with schwannomas is typically unilateral, and these tumors do not typically cause seizures. In addition, these tumors most commonly appear on MRI as a single, contrast-enhancing lesion near the cerebellopontine angle.
Image Description:

Cranial MRI
Upper left: T2-weighted image (axial view)
Lower left and right: T1-weighted images after application of contrast agent (axial and coronal views)

A tumor is visible on the right side between the brainstem and the cerebellum (green overlay), extending into the porus acousticus (arrow). There is strong contrast enhancement within the lesion and it has a hypointense center (red overlay), suggesting necrosis.

G) CORRECT:

Glioblastoma multiforme is a very aggressive tumor of adulthood (peak incidence of 60–70 years of age) that can manifest with altered mental status, seizures, headaches, and focal neurologic deficits. On MRI, they classically appear as ring-enhancing masses (due to central necrosis) with perifocal edema. Glioblastomas are typically located in the cerebral white matter (e.g., left temporal lobe), although they can cross the midline (butterfly glioma). This condition has a poor prognosis with a median survival time of ∼ 1 year.
Image Description:

T1-weighted contrast-enhanced MRI, frontal view: bihemisphere garland-like contrast enhancement. There is peripheral contrast agent enhancement (blue overlay) with central necrosis (green overlay). The third ventricle (arrowhead) is centrally located. The tumor is displacing the posterior horn of the lateral ventricle (red overlay). Diagnosis: bilateral glioblastoma (butterfly glioma).

H) INCORRECT:

Meningiomas are slow-growing tumors that can cause altered mental status, seizures, and headaches. Though these tumors are the most common primary central nervous system tumors in adults (with a peak incidence in the sixth decade of life), they typically appear on MRI as homogeneous, enhancing masses that arise from the dura with no associated necrosis or rim enhancement.
Image Description:

MRI head (T1-weighted; with contrast; sagittal plane)

There is a well-circumscribed homogeneous mass (green overlay) along the cerebral convexity. It demonstrates intense, homogeneous enhancement, equivalent to that of adjacent dura mater. Displacement without invasion of the surrounding white matter supports an extra-axial location.

This is a case of meningioma, a dural-based tumor. The dura is represented in this image by the thin, discontinuously enhancing line covering the inner surface of the skull (indicated by arrowhead).

I) INCORRECT:

Craniopharyngiomas are brain tumors that have a bimodal distribution of age (children 5–14 years of age and adults 50–75 years of age). These tumors can cause altered mental status and headaches due to obstructive hydrocephalus and traction on surrounding structures but do not typically cause seizures. In addition, they often cause other symptoms, including hyperprolactinemia and central diabetes insipidus (from compression of the anterior or posterior pituitary gland), none of which are seen in this patient. Moreover, they often show calcifications and cysts on MRI.
Image Description:

MRI of the brain (T1-weighted; sagittal view; with contrast)

A hyperintense, ovoid, sharply demarcated lesion (green overlay) is visible within the sella turcica and partially extends into the sphenoidal sinus.

The location and appearance of the lesion suggest a craniopharyngioma or a pituitary adenoma.

J) INCORRECT:

Colorectal cancer that metastasizes to the brain can cause altered mental status, seizures, and headaches. Risk factors for colorectal cancer include smoking and chronic constipation. However, colorectal cancer typically initially manifests with abdominal symptoms (e.g., gastrointestinal bleeding) and only metastasizes late in the disease course. In addition, brain metastases typically manifest on MRI as multiple, circumscribed lesions with perifocal edema, not a single mass.

K) INCORRECT:

Optic gliomas are low-grade, astrocytic tumors that can cause headaches. However, they do not typically cause seizures. In addition, they often result in visual impairment due to involvement of the optic nerve and/or chiasm, which is not seen in this patient. Moreover, optic gliomas most commonly occur in early childhood (90% before 10 years of age).
Image Description:

MRI head (T2-weighted; axial plane)

There is a large hyperintense mass (green overlay) in the left intraconal space displacing the ocular globe out of the orbital cavity (exophthalmos). The intraconal space is located posterior to the globe and contained within the cone formed by the recti muscles. The mass is well-defined and displaces rather than invades surrounding structures. The left optic nerve is not visualized on this image, and the mass either arises from it or displaces it. The normal-appearing right optic nerve (red overlay) is well visualized.

The differential diagnosis for intraconal masses depends on whether or not the lesion is continuous with the optic nerve. Differential diagnoses for masses involving the optic nerve include, but are not limited to, meningioma, glioma, and lymphoma. Differential diagnoses for masses not involving the nerve include, but are not limited to, hemangioma, schwannoma, and rhabdomyosarcoma.

L) INCORRECT:

Pinealomas are rare brain tumors that can cause headaches. However, they usually develop in children, not adults, and do not typically cause seizures. In addition, these tumors develop in the pineal region and typically have a cystic appearance on MRI.
questions.hint: A biopsy specimen of this patient's tumor will most likely stain positive for glial fibrillary acidic protein.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance 40 minutes after a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. According to his son, who had called the ambulance, the patient has had headaches and mild nausea for the past 3 weeks. His father “has been acting really strange recently.” The patient has no other history of serious illness. He does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. His only medication is a daily fish oil supplement. He is oriented only to person. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. An MRI of the brain is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Grade IV astrocytomas (glioblastomas) are highly malignant, rapidly progressive brain tumors that commonly manifest with nonspecific neurological symptoms such as altered mental status, seizures, headaches, and nausea that progress over days to weeks. Similar to what is seen on this patient's MRI, grade IV astrocytomas classically appear as ring-enhancing masses (due to central necrosis) with perifocal edema. These tumors are typically located in the supratentorial white matter of the cerebral hemispheres (e.g., left temporal lobe), and may cross the midline (i.e., butterfly glioma). The prognosis of this condition is poor, with a median survival time of ∼ 1 year.

B) INCORRECT:

Hemangioblastomas are rare, benign, slow-growing, highly vascularized tumors that most commonly develop in adults (usually between 20–50 years of age) and can cause altered mental status, seizures, and headaches. However, unlike this patient's supratentorial tumor, hemangioblastomas are typically located in the cerebellum or brainstem (infratentorial) and appear on MRI as T2-hyperintense, nodular lesions with cystic components.
Image Description:

MRI head (with contrast; axial view)

A brightly enhancing, sharply delimited nodular mass (white arrow) with nonenhancing, cystic areas is visible within the right cerebellar hemisphere.

These findings are consistent with cerebellar hemangioblastoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Meningiomas are slow-growing tumors that can cause altered mental status, seizures, and headaches. However, meningiomas are usually asymptomatic and found incidentally on imaging. Although these tumors are the most common primary central nervous system tumors in adults (with a peak incidence in the sixth decade of life), they typically appear on MRI as homogeneous, enhancing masses that arise from the dura with no associated necrosis or rim enhancement.
Image Description:

Cranial MRI (T1-weighted, transverse and sagittal views, with contrast)

Round lesion in the pineal region (green overlay) showing pronounced and homogeneous enhancement (snowball appearance). There is no perifocal edema, which indicates slow tumor growth. The discretely dilated third ventricle (3) is located in front of the lesion, the dilated lateral ventricle (1) is located laterally (upper image) and cranially (lower image) to the lesion, and the cistern of the great cerebral vein (2, white hatched outline) can be seen caudal to it.

D) INCORRECT:

Brain abscesses most commonly occur due to the contiguous spread of bacteria following infection of the ears, nose, mouth, or meninges. Typical symptoms include fever, headache, signs of elevated intracranial pressure, and generalized or focal seizures. On MRI, a brain abscess appears as a ring-enhancing lesion. However, this patient does not have any signs of infection.
Image Description:

Cranial MRI (with contrast, axial view)

An oval lesion can be seen in the left temporal lobe, with ring-like contrast enhancement (green ring) and central necrosis (green overlay). The perifocal edema (white overlay) that is visible corresponds to the lesion. Differential diagnoses include an abscess, glioblastoma, and metastasis.

Diagnosis: abscess following advanced otitis media

E) INCORRECT:

Medulloblastomas commonly manifest with altered mental status, seizures, and headaches. However, medulloblastomas are more common in children (with a peak incidence at 5–9 years of age), are commonly located in the infratentorial region (e.g., cerebellar midline), and appear on MRI as contrast-enhancing tumors that often compress the fourth ventricle.
Image Description:

Head MRI (T2 weighted image)

Medulloblastoma within the posterior cranial fossa (green border in overlay). The lesion contains cystic areas, particularly on the left side (green overlay).

F) INCORRECT:

Cancers that metastasize to the brain (e.g., lung, melanoma, kidney, and colon cancer) are the most common cause of brain tumors in adults and can cause altered mental status, seizures, and headaches. However, unlike this patient's MRI findings, metastatic lesions typically manifest as multiple, circumscribed lesions with perifocal edema. Moreover, this patient has no history or other systemic complaints that would suggest a malignancy.
Image Description:

MRI head (T2-weighted; without contrast; axial plane) of a patient with lung carcinoma

A solitary, well-circumscribed, predominantly hyperintense mass (hatched overlay) in the left occipital lobe is accompanied by perifocal edema (green overlay).

The lesion is consistent with a cerebral metastasis.
questions.hint: The MRI of the brain shows a lesion in the supratentorial white matter spanning across both hemispheres with irregular, peripheral contrast-enhancing margins, and a necrotic core.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old man with a 2-month history of newly diagnosed, untreated, metastatic non-small-cell lung cancer reports increasing lethargy and falls during the past week. Before this episode, he had notably good performance status, spending more than half the day out of bed and independently engaged in activities of daily living. He has a large, surgically unresectable right-lung tumor with multifocal metastases to the axial skeleton.
On examination, he is afebrile, and his vital signs are normal. Neurologic examination reveals mild weakness and lack of coordination of the left upper extremity. Laboratory results are normal.
A single abnormal lesion, measuring 3 cm, is noted on brain imaging (figure).
In addition to administering dexamethasone, which one of the following management approaches is the best option for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Whole-brain radiation plus glucocorticoid therapy is the treatment of choice for patients with multiple brain metastases.

B) INCORRECT:

Hospice care is particularly appropriate for patients with advanced cancer who are symptomatic, deteriorating, and expected to survive for less than 6 months. This patient has good performance status and should receive available treatment for his brain metastasis if he is interested.

C) INCORRECT:

Surgery is associated with substantial morbidity because it would require a craniotomy, which is a much more invasive procedure than stereotactic radiosurgery. Surgery is generally more appropriate when the number and/or size of the lesions exceeds the threshold for using stereotactic radiosurgery. These thresholds may vary in different centers, but in general, no more than five lesions can be treated, and no lesion can be larger than 3.5 cm.

D) CORRECT:

The most common intracranial tumors in adults are brain metastases. Stereotactic radiosurgery is the most effective approach to managing a single intracerebral metastatic lesion. It is a minimally invasive procedure that is especially suitable for patients with limited metastatic brain disease and relatively good baseline performance status.

The most common primary tumors that metastasize to the brain are lung cancer, melanoma, renal-cell carcinoma, and breast cancer. The clinical manifestation of a brain metastasis depends on the location of the tumor(s) and on whether there is associated edema and increased intracranial pressure producing a midline shift. The imaging features most consistent with a brain metastasis include the presence of multiple lesions, lesions with circumscribed margins, lesions localized at the junction of gray and white matter, and lesions surrounded by extensive vasogenic edema. MRI is preferred over CT for imaging brain metastases.

Key learning point: The most appropriate treatment for a single, small (<3.5 cm) brain metastasis in a patient with unresectable non-small-cell lung cancer is stereotactic radiosurgery.

E) INCORRECT:

Intrathecal methotrexate is suitable for the treatment of carcinomatous or lymphomatous meningitis but not for solitary brain metastases.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man with no significant medical history presents with new-onset headaches and seizures.
Neurologic examination is notable for difficulty repeating sentences, a right visual-field deficit, and sensory changes in the right arm and leg. Cranial nerve examination including funduscopy is normal.
Axial T1-weighted MRI obtained after intravenous administration of gadolinium contrast (figure) shows an avidly enhancing lesion with indistinct margins centered in the left periventricular white matter. There is effacement of the overlying cortical sulci but no significant shift of midline structures or mass effect on surrounding structures.
What is the most appropriate next step in the care of this patient?

choices.text: Perform lumbar puncture and analysis of cerebrospinal fluid

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Palliative care is not an appropriate first step for a patient with primary CNS lymphoma, because this type of lymphoma is very treatable with high-dose chemotherapy with or without radiation therapy.

B) INCORRECT:

Given the necessity of establishing a tissue diagnosis, glucocorticoids are contraindicated, because they could obscure any possible future attempt at tissue biopsy.

C) CORRECT:

This patient’s clinical presentation and MRI findings raise suspicion for primary central nervous system (CNS) lymphoma. Patients with primary CNS lymphomas present with neurologic deficits or seizures rather than the B symptoms (fever, unintentional weight loss, and night sweats) typically seen in patients with systemic lymphomas. On imaging, most CNS lymphomas are supratentorial, clustering around the ventricles, with a predilection for the deep gray matter of the frontal and parietal lobes. The image is not pathognomonic of CNS lymphoma, but because of periventricular location and moderate enhancement, lymphoma must be considered, and lumbar puncture is indicated.

Cytology and flow studies can determine the presence of a monoclonal B-cell population and confirm the diagnosis. Stereotactic biopsy is indicated only when the analysis of cerebrospinal fluid is not diagnostic.

Once the diagnosis of primary CNS lymphoma has been established, initial treatment for most patients involves high-dose systemic chemotherapy.

Key learning point: The most appropriate investigation in a patient with a periventricular brain tumor that has features of a lymphoma is lumbar puncture.

D) INCORRECT:

Stereotactic biopsy is indicated only when the analysis of cerebrospinal fluid is not diagnostic.

E) INCORRECT:

Radiation therapy should not be initiated before the diagnosis is confirmed unless herniation is an imminent threat.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old girl presents for evaluation of progressive, frequent headaches that have occurred during the past 6 months. Her parents report that acetaminophen and ibuprofen initially seemed to resolve the headaches, but these medications are no longer effective. The headaches occur most frequently in the morning and are often associated with vomiting, which resolves the pain. The parents would like their daughter checked for diabetes because she has been drinking and urinating more often during the past month, and they would also like a referral to an eye doctor because she has "been bumping into things lately."
The girl’s growth chart shows that her height has not increased since her last clinic visit 8 months ago. Physical examination reveals diminished peripheral vision and dry skin but no café-au-lait macules. A urine dipstick is remarkable for a specific gravity of 1.002 (reference range, 1.001-1.035). A fingerstick test shows a serum glucose level of 78 mg/dL (reference range, 60–100).
Given the concern for a possible intracranial mass, a CT scan is obtained (figure).
In addition to obtaining surgical consultation, which one of the following next steps in management is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Order MRI of the spinal cord
Administer intravenous fluids, ketorolac, and metoclopramide
Order DNA testing for neurofibromatosis type 1

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

MRI of the spinal cord is not needed at this time, given that craniopharyngiomas do not metastasize.

B) CORRECT:

This patient's clinical presentation and CT scan, showing a suprasellar mass with calcifications, are consistent with a craniopharyngioma. The morning emesis is likely related to increased intracranial pressure, whereas the symptoms of diabetes insipidus are likely related to direct compression of the tumor on the pituitary. The most appropriate next step for this patient is to test for diabetes insipidus by measuring the serum sodium level. One would expect to see hypernatremia and an inappropriately dilute urine for the level of hypernatremia.

Craniopharyngiomas are slow-growing brain tumors that are usually found near the pituitary gland. They cannot spread to other parts of the brain but can cause significant symptoms related to compression of adjacent structures. Symptoms may be present for 1 to 2 years before diagnosis. Headaches, nausea, and emesis (especially in the morning) are related to the increased intracranial pressure. Vision change, often bitemporal hemianopia, occurs because of pressure on the optic chiasm. Pituitary dysfunction, which occurs in the majority of cases of craniopharyngioma, includes growth delay, increased thirst and urination related to diabetes insipidus, and hypothyroidism.

Surgery is the primary treatment for a craniopharyngioma. Patients with recurrent disease may require additional surgeries, radiation, or both. Patients with fully resected lesions often have panhypopituitarism for the rest of their lives.

Key learning point: In addition to obtaining surgical consultation, the most appropriate initial workup for a child who has a suspected craniopharyngioma with polyuria and polydipsia is measurement of serum sodium and urine osmolarity levels.

C) INCORRECT:

Migraine headaches can be associated with vomiting, but this patient’s morning emesis and endocrine abnormalities warrant additional workup for other causes rather than empiric treatment for migraine with fluids, ketorolac, and metoclopramide.

D) INCORRECT:

The patient’s vision concerns include bitemporal hemianopia. Visual field testing is most useful to detect more subtle visual field defects, so while it would confirm the finding, further testing to confirm the hemianopia should not delay other interventions.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with neurofibromatosis type 1 present with central nervous system tumors, but these are most often optic-nerve gliomas, not craniopharyngiomas. Also, the patient does not have any café-au-lait spots, which are commonly seen in individuals with neurofibromatosis type 1.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old boy is evaluated for headaches that began about 3 weeks ago. His mother reports that the headaches were initially intermittent but now occur daily and that the patient has also had emesis twice during the past week, in the mornings before school.
Initial CT of the head reveals a midline, posterior fossa mass. Subsequent MRI of the brain shows a mass arising from the cerebellar vermis and extending into the fourth ventricle, causing obstructive hydrocephalus. MRI of the spine demonstrates multiple nodular contrast-enhancing lesions on the surface of the spinal cord. Lumbar puncture reveals tumor cells in the cerebrospinal fluid.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intracranial germ-cell tumors account for approximately 0.5% of all primary CNS tumors, with peak incidence at age 10 to 19 years. They most commonly arise from the pineal or suprasellar region.

B) INCORRECT:

Diffuse intrinsic pontine gliomas are less common than medulloblastomas and occur in the brainstem; they do not enhance on a contrast MRI.

C) INCORRECT:

Atypical teratoid rhabdoid tumors are rare, aggressive embryonal CNS tumors of childhood that can occur in the posterior fossa. These tumors usually have heterogenous enhancement and irregular margins, whereas medulloblastomas usually have well-defined borders. The biggest difference between these two types of tumors is age at onset, as atypical teratoid rhabdoid tumors usually occur in younger children, including infants.

D) INCORRECT:

Pilocytic astrocytoma can also be found as midline, cerebellar tumors; however, they typically grow slowly (with symptoms present for months, not weeks, at the time of diagnosis), and metastatic disease is rare.

E) CORRECT:

Medulloblastoma is a primary malignant embryonal tumor of the central nervous system (CNS) occurring exclusively in the posterior fossa. Incidence peaks in the first decade of life and is highest in children aged 5 to 7 years; there is a slight male predominance. Because medulloblastoma typically arises from the cerebellar vermis and invades the fourth ventricle, the most common symptoms at presentation are those associated with obstructive hydrocephalus — headaches, nausea, vomiting, truncal ataxia, and cranial nerve palsies. Medulloblastoma is typically contrast enhancing on MRI and has the potential for leptomeningeal spread and drop metastases to the spine.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a 5-year-old child with daily headaches, vomiting, and a posterior fossa mass on MRI is medulloblastoma.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance 40 minutes after a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. According to his son, who had called the ambulance, the patient has had headaches and mild nausea for the past 3 weeks. His father “has been acting really strange recently.” The patient has no other history of serious illness. Vital signs are within normal limits. An MRI of the brain is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Grade IV astrocytomas (glioblastomas) are highly malignant, rapidly progressive brain tumors that commonly manifest with nonspecific neurological symptoms such as altered mental status, seizures, headaches, and nausea that progress over days to weeks. Similar to what is seen on this patient's MRI, grade IV astrocytomas classically appear as ring-enhancing masses (due to central necrosis) with perifocal edema. These tumors are typically located in the supratentorial white matter of the cerebral hemispheres (e.g., left temporal lobe), and may cross the midline (i.e., butterfly glioma). The prognosis of this condition is poor, with a median survival time of ∼ 1 year.

B) INCORRECT:

Hemangioblastomas are rare, benign, slow-growing, highly vascularized tumors that most commonly develop in adults (usually between 20–50 years of age) and can cause altered mental status, seizures, and headaches. However, unlike this patient's supratentorial tumor, hemangioblastomas are typically located in the cerebellum or brainstem (infratentorial) and appear on MRI as T2-hyperintense, nodular lesions with cystic components.
Image Description:

MRI head (with contrast; axial view)

A brightly enhancing, sharply delimited nodular mass (white arrow) with nonenhancing, cystic areas is visible within the right cerebellar hemisphere.

These findings are consistent with cerebellar hemangioblastoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Meningiomas are slow-growing tumors that can cause altered mental status, seizures, and headaches. However, meningiomas are usually asymptomatic and found incidentally on imaging. Although these tumors are the most common primary central nervous system tumors in adults (with a peak incidence in the sixth decade of life), they typically appear on MRI as homogeneous, enhancing masses that arise from the dura with no associated necrosis or rim enhancement.
Image Description:

Cranial MRI (T1-weighted, transverse and sagittal views, with contrast)

Round lesion in the pineal region (green overlay) showing pronounced and homogeneous enhancement (snowball appearance). There is no perifocal edema, which indicates slow tumor growth. The discretely dilated third ventricle (3) is located in front of the lesion, the dilated lateral ventricle (1) is located laterally (upper image) and cranially (lower image) to the lesion, and the cistern of the great cerebral vein (2, white hatched outline) can be seen caudal to it.

D) INCORRECT:

Medulloblastomas commonly manifest with altered mental status, seizures, and headaches. However, medulloblastomas are more common in children (with a peak incidence at 5–9 years of age), are commonly located in the infratentorial region (e.g., cerebellar midline), and appear on MRI as contrast-enhancing tumors that often compress the fourth ventricle.
Image Description:

Head MRI (T2 weighted image)

Medulloblastoma within the posterior cranial fossa (green border in overlay). The lesion contains cystic areas, particularly on the left side (green overlay).

E) INCORRECT:

Cancers that metastasize to the brain (e.g., lung, melanoma, kidney, and colon cancer) are the most common cause of brain tumors in adults and can cause altered mental status, seizures, and headaches. However, unlike this patient's MRI findings, metastatic lesions typically manifest as multiple, circumscribed lesions with perifocal edema. Moreover, this patient has no history or other systemic complaints that would suggest a malignancy.
Image Description:

MRI head (T2-weighted; without contrast; axial plane) of a patient with lung carcinoma

A solitary, well-circumscribed, predominantly hyperintense mass (hatched overlay) in the left occipital lobe is accompanied by perifocal edema (green overlay).

The lesion is consistent with a cerebral metastasis.
questions.hint: The MRI of the brain shows a lesion in the supratentorial white matter spanning across both hemispheres with irregular, peripheral contrast-enhancing margins, and a necrotic core.

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl is brought to the office because of a 4-month history of early morning headaches and worsening fatigue. The headaches are often accompanied by nausea and vomiting. She stopped going to her ballet lessons 2 weeks ago because she was embarrassed about falling frequently and having increasing difficulty performing the steps. She has a broad-based gait. She is unable to perform rapid, alternating movements with her hands. An MRI of the brain is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acoustic schwannomas can present with vertigo and/or dizziness that result in falls. However, patients will more commonly present with sensorineural hearing loss, which this patient lacks. More importantly, acoustic neuromas are found within the internal acoustic canal along CN VIII or within the cerebral hemispheres. Imaging for acoustic schwannoma would also show a cystic lesion with nodular parts. Finally, acoustic schwannomas occur rarely in children.
Image Description:

Cranial MRI
Upper left: T2-weighted image (axial view)
Lower left and right: T1-weighted images after application of contrast agent (axial and coronal views)

A tumor is visible on the right side between the brainstem and the cerebellum (green overlay), extending into the porus acousticus (arrow). There is strong contrast enhancement within the lesion and it has a hypointense center (red overlay), suggesting necrosis.

B) CORRECT:

Pilocytic astrocytoma is the most common brain tumor in children and is usually located within the posterior fossa. Cerebellar compression can cause falls and dysdiadochokinesia, while increased intracranial pressure can result in lethargy, morning headaches, nausea, and vomiting. Imaging typically shows a well-circumscribed, enhancing cystic mass within one of the cerebellar hemispheres, but it can also occur in the cerebral hemispheres. Since pilocytic astrocytomas are low-grade tumors (WHO grade I), patients usually have a favorable prognosis following surgical resection.

Medulloblastoma and pilocytic astrocytoma are the most common posterior cranial fossa tumors in children. Medulloblastoma is the most common malignant brain tumor in children.

C) INCORRECT:

Oligodendroglioma can cause signs of increased intracranial pressure. However, these tumors are usually located supratentorial rather than in the posterior fossa, which is why patients with oligodendroglioma tend to also have seizures and/or focal neurological deficits. Furthermore, oligodendrogliomas usually affect adults 40–50 years of age, not children.
Image Description:

Cranial CT scan (axial view)

A large hypodense lesion (green overlay) with multiple intralesional hyperdense calcifications (yellow overlay) is visible in the temporal lobe.

D) INCORRECT:

Brainstem glioma can cause signs of increased intracranial pressure (i.e., morning headaches, nausea, and vomiting) and cerebellar signs (broad-based gait, dysdiadochokinesia). However, due to brainstem involvement in this condition, cranial nerve deficits are typically seen (e.g., diplopia, facial droop) and symptoms usually develop over the course of a few days, not months. Imaging usually shows minimal contrast enhancement rather than a contrast-enhancing cystic mass.

E) INCORRECT:

Craniopharyngiomas can present with signs of increased intracranial pressure (i.e., morning headaches, nausea, and vomiting), but are located within the sellar or suprasellar region, not the posterior fossa. Additionally, this patient lacks other findings of craniopharyngioma, such as vision changes from optic chiasm compression (e.g., bitemporal hemianopsia) and/or hormonal imbalances from pituitary compression (e.g., short stature, delayed puberty). Also, ataxia is not seen with this type of tumor.

F) INCORRECT:

Ependymoma can cause signs of increased intracranial pressure (i.e., morning headaches, nausea, and vomiting) and cerebellar signs (broad-based gait, dysdiadochokinesia). However, these tumors typically arise from the floor of the fourth ventricle, adapt to the shape of the ventricle, and extend through the foramina of Luschka and Magendi into the cisterns. It would be unusual for the tumor not to invade the ventricles and have cystic components on imaging. Furthermore, patients with ependymomas tend to be younger than this patient.
Image Description:

MRI brain (FLAIR; sagittal view)

A well-defined heterogeneous hyperintense lesion is visible within the expanded 4th ventricle (green overlay). At the superior aspect of the lesion, multiple dark foci are present (arrowheads), representing cysts. They appear dark in this image as the fluid signal is removed on FLAIR sequences. This lesion has obstructed circulation of the cerebrospinal fluid, resulting in ventriculomegaly (indicated by dashed line).

Ependymomas commonly arise within the fourth ventricle. They are usually hyperintense on T2 weighted/FLAIR images and can demonstrate cystic change, such as in this case, as well as hemorrhage.
questions.hint: The MRI scan shows a large (3.5 cm), well-defined, contrast-enhancing cystic mass in the lateral posterior fossa without ventricular involvement.

questions.text: You are seeing a 57-year-old man who is brought to the emergency department by his wife 20 minutes after experiencing a seizure. He has had recurrent headaches and dizziness for the past 2 weeks. MRI of the brain reveals multiple, round, well-demarcated lesions in the brain parenchyma at the junction between gray and white matter. The cells comprising these brain lesions most likely originate from which one of the following organs?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although breast cancers have a tendency to metastasize to the brain, they are not the most common origin of brain metastases. Moreover, cancers of the breast rarely occur in men.

B) INCORRECT:

Thyroid cancers that spread hematogenously (i.e., follicular thyroid cancer, anaplastic thyroid cancer, and medullary thyroid cancer) predominantly metastasize to the bone and lung but rarely to the brain. Papillary thyroid cancer metastasizes predominantly through lymphatics to the regional lymph nodes; distant metastases from papillary thyroid cancer are uncommon.

C) INCORRECT:

Renal cell carcinoma most frequently metastasizes to the lungs as the tumor emboli enter the renal vein and inferior vena cava and reach the lungs via the pulmonary artery. Although kidney cancers may rarely metastasize to the brain, they are not the most common origin of brain metastases.

D) INCORRECT:

Colon cancer classically metastasizes hematogenously first to the liver, as venous blood from the colon drains into the portal vein and the hepatic sinusoids, seeding the tumor emboli within the liver parenchyma. Although colon cancers have a tendency to metastasize to the brain, they are not the most common origin of brain metastases.

E) CORRECT:

Primary cancers of the lung (particularly small cell lung cancer and adenocarcinoma of the lung) are the most common origin of brain metastases. The 2nd most common origin of brain metastases are cancers of the breast followed by melanoma and cancers of the kidney and colon. Metastatic disease accounts for approx. 50% of all brain tumors.

See “Common origins of cancer metastases” table.

Key learning point: Lung cancer is the most common primary source of brain metastases, followed by breast cancer, melanoma, kidney, and colon cancers.
