Image Description:

Arrows have been color-coded according to the site of the primary tumor:

Pink: skin cancer
Blue: breast cancer
Green: lung cancer
Orange: pancreatic cancer
Red: colon cancer
Lime: ovarian cancer

The table provides examples of suffixes used to specify the affected organs according to the TNM classification.
questions.hint: The junction between the gray and white matter is the typical location for brain metastases, the most common type of intracranial tumors, which visualize as round, well-demarcated intraparenchymal lesions on MRI.

questions.text: You are seeing a 52-year-old man who is brought to the emergency department by ambulance 40 minutes after experiencing a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. His son reports that the patient has had headaches and mild nausea for the past 3 weeks, and has been acting unusually during this time. He has no significant past medical history. Vital signs are normal. An MRI of the brain is provided. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Grade IV astrocytomas (glioblastomas) are highly malignant, rapidly progressive brain tumors that commonly manifest with nonspecific neurological symptoms such as altered mental status, seizures, headaches, and nausea that progress over days to weeks. Similar to what is seen on this patient's MRI, grade IV astrocytomas classically appear as ring-enhancing masses (due to central necrosis) with perifocal edema. These tumors are typically located in the supratentorial white matter of the cerebral hemispheres (e.g., left temporal lobe), and may cross the midline (i.e., butterfly glioma). The prognosis of this condition is poor, with a median survival time of ∼ 1 year.

Key learning point: Glioblastoma multiforme (grade IV astrocytoma) is a highly malignant, rapidly progressive brain tumor that appears as a ring-enhancing mass with central necrosis and edema, often crossing the midline, and carries a poor prognosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Meningiomas are slow-growing tumors that can cause altered mental status, seizures, and headaches. However, meningiomas are usually asymptomatic and found incidentally on imaging. Although these tumors are the most common primary central nervous system tumors in adults (with a peak incidence in the sixth decade of life), they typically appear on MRI as homogeneous, enhancing masses that arise from the dura with no associated necrosis or rim enhancement.

C) INCORRECT:

Cancers that metastasize to the brain (e.g., lung, melanoma, kidney, and colon cancer) are the most common cause of brain tumors in adults and can cause altered mental status, seizures, and headaches. However, unlike this patient's MRI findings, metastatic lesions typically manifest as multiple, circumscribed lesions with perifocal edema. Moreover, this patient has no history or other systemic complaints that would suggest a malignancy.

D) INCORRECT:

Hemangioblastomas are rare, benign, slow-growing, highly vascularized tumors that most commonly develop in adults (usually between 20–50 years of age) and can cause altered mental status, seizures, and headaches. However, unlike this patient's supratentorial tumor, hemangioblastomas are typically located in the cerebellum or brainstem (infratentorial) and appear on MRI as T2-hyperintense, nodular lesions with cystic components.

E) INCORRECT:

Medulloblastomas commonly manifest with altered mental status, seizures, and headaches. However, medulloblastomas are more common in children (with a peak incidence at 5–9 years of age), are commonly located in the infratentorial region (e.g., cerebellar midline), and appear on MRI as contrast-enhancing tumors that often compress the fourth ventricle.
questions.hint: The MRI of the brain shows a lesion in the supratentorial white matter spanning across both hemispheres with irregular, peripheral contrast-enhancing margins, and a necrotic core.

questions.text: You are seeing a 9-year-old girl who is brought to your clinic with a 4-month history of early morning headaches and worsening fatigue. Her headaches are often associated with nausea and vomiting. Two weeks ago, she stopped attending ballet lessons due to frequent falls and increasing difficulty with movement. On examination, she has a broad-based gait and is unable to perform rapid, alternating movements with her hands. An MRI of the brain is provided. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Brainstem glioma can cause signs of increased intracranial pressure (i.e., morning headaches, nausea, and vomiting) and cerebellar signs (broad-based gait, dysdiadochokinesia). However, due to brainstem involvement in this condition, cranial nerve deficits are typically seen (e.g., diplopia, facial droop) and symptoms usually develop over the course of a few days, not months. Imaging usually shows minimal contrast enhancement rather than a contrast-enhancing cystic mass.

B) INCORRECT:

Oligodendroglioma can cause signs of increased intracranial pressure. However, these tumors are usually located supratentorial rather than in the posterior fossa, which is why patients with oligodendroglioma tend to also have seizures and/or focal neurological deficits. Furthermore, oligodendrogliomas usually affect adults 40–50 years of age, not children.

C) CORRECT:

Pilocytic astrocytoma is the most common brain tumor in children and is usually located within the posterior fossa. Cerebellar compression can cause falls and dysdiadochokinesia, while increased intracranial pressure can result in lethargy, morning headaches, nausea, and vomiting. Imaging typically shows a well-circumscribed, enhancing cystic mass within one of the cerebellar hemispheres, but it can also occur in the cerebral hemispheres. Since pilocytic astrocytomas are low-grade tumors (WHO grade I), patients usually have a favorable prognosis following surgical resection.

Medulloblastoma and pilocytic astrocytoma are the most common posterior cranial fossa tumors in children. Medulloblastoma is the most common malignant brain tumor in children.

Key learning point: Pilocytic astrocytoma is the most common pediatric brain tumor, typically presenting as a well-circumscribed, cystic, contrast-enhancing mass in the cerebellum with symptoms of increased intracranial pressure and cerebellar dysfunction.

D) INCORRECT:

Ependymoma can cause signs of increased intracranial pressure (i.e., morning headaches, nausea, and vomiting) and cerebellar signs (broad-based gait, dysdiadochokinesia). However, these tumors typically arise from the floor of the fourth ventricle, adapt to the shape of the ventricle, and extend through the foramina of Luschka and Magendi into the cisterns. It would be unusual for the tumor not to invade the ventricles and have cystic components on imaging. Furthermore, patients with ependymomas tend to be younger than this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Craniopharyngiomas can present with signs of increased intracranial pressure (i.e., morning headaches, nausea, and vomiting), but are located within the sellar or suprasellar region, not the posterior fossa. Additionally, this patient lacks other findings of craniopharyngioma, such as vision changes from optic chiasm compression (e.g., bitemporal hemianopsia) and/or hormonal imbalances from pituitary compression (e.g., short stature, delayed puberty). Also, ataxia is not seen with this type of tumor.
questions.hint: The MRI scan shows a large (3.5 cm), well-defined, contrast-enhancing cystic mass in the lateral posterior fossa without ventricular involvement.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents with his wife after experiencing a witnessed generalized tonic-clonic seizure at home. He has had progressive morning headaches for the past month that worsen with coughing. His wife reports he has been increasingly forgetful and has difficulty finding words. Examination shows subtle left-sided weakness and papilledema. He has no history of seizures, head trauma, or substance abuse. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: MRI of the brain with gadolinium
CT angiography of the head and neck

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lumbar puncture is contraindicated in this patient with signs of elevated intracranial pressure, including papilledema, as lumbar puncture could precipitate brain herniation.

B) INCORRECT:

While an electroencephalogram may be used for seizure evaluation, it would not identify the underlying structural cause of this patient's symptoms. Emergency neuroimaging takes priority when a space-occupying lesion is suspected.

C) INCORRECT:

While MRI with gadolinium is the gold standard for brain tumor evaluation, it is not immediately available in most emergency departments and takes significantly longer to obtain than other imaging modalities. Given the clinical concern for elevated intracranial pressure and possible intracranial bleeding, an alternative approach would be more appropriate in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- Noncontrast CT head is the most appropriate initial imaging study for a suspected brain tumor that might be complicated by intracranial bleeding or elevated intracranial pressure. This patient's presentation of new-onset seizures, progressive morning headaches, focal neurological deficits, cognitive changes, and papilledema requires immediate neuroimaging to evaluate for mass effect, midline shift, and other life-threatening complications. While MRI is more sensitive for tumor detection, CT is readily available, faster to complete, and can identify significant mass lesions or complications requiring urgent intervention.

E) INCORRECT:

CT angiography evaluates vascular structures and would be appropriate for suspected acute vascular pathology, such as stroke or aneurysm. This patient's insidious symptom progression over weeks, morning headache pattern, and examination findings strongly suggest a primary mass lesion. The acute seizures and signs of elevated intracranial pressure could be caused by the mass itself or bleeding around the mass. Contrast in CT angiography can obscure the appearance of acute bleeding; therefore, an alternative approach is required in this patient.

questions.text: A 38-year-old patient presents with a 3-week history of progressive headaches and a witnessed seizure. Physical examination shows subtle left-sided weakness and mild confusion. Brain MRI with contrast is shown. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Order lumbar puncture with CSF analysis
Start antiepileptic therapy and discharge with outpatient follow-up
Obtain whole-body imaging to evaluate for primary malignancy
Initiate high-dose dexamethasone and consult neurosurgery

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Empiric antibiotics would be indicated for brain abscesses, which typically show ring enhancement and a more irregular, thick-walled appearance. Moreover, brain abscesses typically occur in patients with predisposing factors such as immunosuppression or systemic infection. The homogeneous enhancement pattern and sharply demarcated borders seen here are not characteristic of an abscess.

B) INCORRECT:

Lumbar puncture is contraindicated in patients with brain lesions causing mass effect due to risk for herniation. The imaging shows significant mass effect with surrounding edema.

C) INCORRECT:

While antiepileptic therapy is appropriate for seizure management, discharging this patient would be unsafe. The brain mass has already caused seizures and neurological symptoms (weakness, confusion), indicating an active mass effect. Without immediate treatment, the patient is at risk for further seizures, worsening neurological decline, and/or increased intracranial pressure at home, where monitoring is impossible.

D) INCORRECT:

While metastatic disease should be considered in adults with brain lesions, the homogeneous enhancement pattern and intraventricular location are more consistent with primary tumors such as ependymoma than metastases. Additionally, this patient has active neurological symptoms from mass effect requiring immediate management before staging studies.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- The imaging shows an intraventricular mass with significant surrounding edema causing mass effect. Immediate management should include dexamethasone to reduce cerebral edema and urgent neurosurgical consult for definitive diagnosis and treatment planning. The location and enhancement pattern suggest a primary intraventricular tumor requiring tissue diagnosis.

questions.text: A 69-year-old man with a history of hypertension presents with a 2-week history of worsening morning headaches and intermittent episodes of word-finding difficulty. His spouse reports he has been increasingly irritable and forgetful. Examination shows mild papilledema, left facial droop, left-sided weakness, and mild dysphasia. Vital signs are normal. CT head is shown. Neurosurgery has been consulted. What is the most appropriate interim management?

choices.text: Perform lumbar puncture and CSF analysis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lumbar puncture is contraindicated in patients with suspected brain tumors and signs of increased intracranial pressure due to the risk of cerebral herniation. This patient's neuroimaging already demonstrates a mass lesion with surrounding edema.

B) INCORRECT:

Primary seizure prophylaxis with levetiracetam is not recommended for brain tumors. The patient has not experienced seizures, and prophylactic antiepileptic drugs are not supported by evidence for preventing brain tumor-associated seizures.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – The patient has clear signs of elevated intracranial pressure (ICP), including papilledema, morning headaches, and imaging showing vasogenic cerebral edema with mass effect. Glucocorticoids such as dexamethasone are indicated for patients with signs of elevated ICP and cerebral edema to reduce brain swelling. While hyperosmolar therapies for ICP management, like mannitol, are also appropriate for elevated ICP, dexamethasone is the preferred initial intervention for tumor-related cerebral edema.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient's CT already establishes the diagnosis of a brain tumor with vasogenic cerebral edema. While gadolinium-enhanced MRI will eventually be needed for better tumor characterization, the immediate priority is medical management of elevated intracranial pressure.

E) INCORRECT:

Therapeutic hyperventilation is usually reserved for patients with severe increased intracranial pressure (ICP) or impending herniation refractory to medical therapies, as a temporizing measure while awaiting surgical treatment. In this conscious patient, hyperosmolar therapies for ICP management or other targeted medication for vasogenic cerebral edema would be more appropriate initial therapy

questions.text: A 65-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife due to a new-onset seizure. She reports that for the past two months, he has had progressive morning headaches, personality changes, including increased irritability, and difficulty with word-finding. He has a history of hypertension. He appears confused. Physical examination shows a left-sided pronator drift and hyperreflexia in the left extremities. A contrast-enhanced MRI of the brain shows a 4-cm, irregularly marginated mass in the right frontal lobe with significant surrounding vasogenic edema. The lesion demonstrates peripheral gadolinium uptake with central necrosis and extends across the corpus callosum. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Brain metastases are the most common intracranial tumors and often present as ring-enhancing lesions with significant edema. However, they are typically multiple, well-circumscribed, and located at the gray-white matter junction. While a single metastasis is possible, extension across the corpus callosum is highly atypical for metastatic disease, which usually spreads hematogenously.

B) INCORRECT:

A tuberculoma can appear as a ring-enhancing mass and cause seizures. This diagnosis is less likely given the absence of risk factors or systemic symptoms of tuberculosis, such as fever, night sweats, or weight loss. Furthermore, the rapid two-month progression of symptoms is more characteristic of a high-grade malignancy than an infectious granuloma.

C) INCORRECT:

Primary CNS lymphoma can present as a ring-enhancing mass and cause similar neurologic deficits. However, it is most common in immunocompromised individuals, which this patient is not. While it can occur in immunocompetent patients, it typically presents as a solitary, periventricular mass with more homogeneous enhancement. The described centrally necrotic, midline-crossing lesion is less typical of lymphoma.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's rapidly progressive symptoms of morning headaches, personality changes, and focal neurologic deficits, in combination with the pathognomonic MRI findings of a large, solitary, intra-axial mass with irregular, ring-like enhancement, central necrosis, and significant vasogenic edema that extends across the corpus callosum to create a characteristic "butterfly glioma" appearance, are consistent with glioblastoma multiforme. It is the most common and aggressive primary malignant brain tumor in adults, typically presenting in older individuals.

E) INCORRECT:

Meningiomas are common tumors in this age group and can cause seizures from mass effect. However, they are typically extra-axial, dural-based masses that enhance intensely and homogeneously, often with a "dural tail" sign. The lesion described is intra-axial (within the brain parenchyma) with central necrosis and irregular margins, which is inconsistent with a typical meningioma.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to 3 weeks of progressive confusion, lethargy, and worsening headaches. Over the past 2 days, he has developed weakness in his right arm and leg. He has a history of HIV and does not adhere to his medication regimen. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F). He is oriented only to person. Physical examination shows right-sided hemiparesis with an upgoing plantar reflex. Laboratory studies reveal a CD4 count of 45 cells/mm3. A contrast-enhanced MRI of the brain reveals a solitary, weakly ring-enhancing, 3-cm lesion in the periventricular white matter. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cryptococcal infection is a common opportunistic infection in AIDS, but it typically causes meningitis, presenting with subacute headache, fever, and signs of increased intracranial pressure. Focal neurologic deficits are uncommon. MRI in cryptococcal meningitis is often normal or shows meningeal enhancement, not a solitary parenchymal mass as seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Cerebral toxoplasmosis is the most common cause of CNS mass lesions in patients with AIDS and presents with similar neurologic symptoms. However, imaging typically reveals multiple, strongly ring-enhancing lesions, often located in the basal ganglia or at the gray-white matter junction. This patient's MRI shows a solitary and weakly enhancing lesion, making this diagnosis less likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) is caused by JC virus reactivation in severely immunocompromised patients and presents with progressive focal neurologic deficits. However, MRI characteristically shows multiple, asymmetric, non-enhancing white matter lesions without mass effect. This patient's imaging shows a solitary, ring-enhancing lesion, which is inconsistent with PML.

D) INCORRECT:

A tuberculous brain abscess, or tuberculoma, can occur in immunocompromised patients and present as a space-occupying lesion. While it can be a solitary, ring-enhancing lesion, the patient is afebrile, and the weak, irregular enhancement in a periventricular location is less typical for a tuberculoma, which often has a more defined, thicker ring of enhancement.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's clinical presentation of headaches, altered mental status, and focal neurologic deficits on physical examination, together with a solitary, weakly ring-enhancing lesion located in the periventricular white matter, is consistent with primary cerebral lymphoma (PCL). This condition is the second most common cause of a CNS mass in patients with AIDS, particularly when the CD4 count is below 50 cells/mm3. It is an aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma strongly associated with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection in this population. Definitive diagnosis is made by brain biopsy, but a positive EBV DNA in the CSF is highly suggestive.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the clinic due to a 3-month history of progressive clumsiness and morning headaches. The headaches are often accompanied by non-bilious vomiting, which provides transient relief. His parents report he has been stumbling frequently and has difficulty with coordinated movements. On physical examination, funduscopy reveals bilateral papilledema. Neurologic testing demonstrates truncal ataxia and dysmetria on finger-to-nose testing. An MRI of the brain reveals a well-demarcated, 4-cm cystic lesion in the cerebellar hemisphere with a brightly enhancing mural nodule. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is classic for a pilocytic astrocytoma, the most common primary brain tumor in children. These are typically slow-growing, benign (WHO grade I) tumors located in the posterior fossa, most often in the cerebellum. The cerebellar location explains the ataxia and dysmetria. Mass effect on the fourth ventricle leads to obstructive hydrocephalus, causing signs of increased intracranial pressure like morning headaches, vomiting, and papilledema. The MRI finding of a well-demarcated cystic lesion with a brightly enhancing mural nodule is pathognomonic. Histologically, these tumors are characterized by Rosenthal fibers. Prognosis is excellent with complete surgical resection.

B) INCORRECT:

Ependymomas commonly occur in the posterior fossa in children, arising from the floor of the fourth ventricle and causing obstructive hydrocephalus. While this location can cause symptoms similar to the patient's, these tumors are typically solid masses that grow into and fill the fourth ventricle, rather than presenting as a cystic lesion with a mural nodule in a cerebellar hemisphere.

C) INCORRECT:

Brainstem gliomas are infratentorial tumors that can present with ataxia and signs of increased intracranial pressure in children. However, a key feature of brainstem gliomas is the presence of multiple cranial nerve palsies (e.g., facial droop, diplopia), which are absent in this patient. Imaging would typically show a diffuse, enhancing mass within the brainstem, not a cystic cerebellar lesion.

D) INCORRECT:

Craniopharyngiomas are pediatric tumors that can cause headaches and vomiting. However, they are supratentorial tumors located in the sella or suprasellar region. Their clinical presentation is dominated by endocrine dysfunction (e.g., growth failure) and visual disturbances (e.g., bitemporal hemianopsia) from optic chiasm compression, not the cerebellar signs seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

A medulloblastoma is a plausible consideration as it is the most common malignant pediatric brain tumor and typically arises in the posterior fossa (cerebellar vermis), causing ataxia and hydrocephalus. However, on imaging, medulloblastomas are classically solid, densely enhancing masses and do not typically present as a cyst with a mural nodule.
questions.hint: The combination of cerebellar signs in a child with the classic MRI finding of a cystic mass with an enhancing mural nodule is highly suggestive of this condition.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife due to a seizure. She reports that for the past two months, he has had worsening morning headaches, personality changes, and memory difficulties. Today, he experienced involuntary twitching of his right arm that progressed to a generalized tonic-clonic seizure lasting two minutes. His medical history is significant for hypertension. On examination, he is postictal but arousable. Vital signs are normal. Neurologic examination shows 4/5 strength in the right upper extremity with a pronator drift. Funduscopic examination shows bilateral papilledema. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An ischemic stroke can cause focal weakness and seizures. However, a stroke is an acute event. This patient's presentation is distinguished by a two-month history of progressively worsening symptoms, such as headaches and personality changes, prior to the seizure. Papilledema also indicates a subacute or chronic process of rising intracranial pressure, not an acute vascular event.

B) INCORRECT:

Cerebral metastases are a common cause of brain tumors in this age group and can present with identical symptoms. However, they arise from a primary cancer elsewhere in the body, such as the lung, breast, or skin (melanoma). In the absence of a known primary malignancy or suggestive symptoms such as cough or weight loss, the most common primary brain tumor is a more likely diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Primary CNS lymphoma can present with focal deficits and cognitive changes. However, it is most commonly seen in patients with significant immunosuppression (e.g., HIV/AIDS, post-transplant). While primary CNS lymphoma can occur in immunocompetent individuals, a different condition is statistically far more probable because this patient has no history of immunodeficiency.

D) CORRECT:

Glioblastoma is the most common and aggressive primary brain tumor in adults, typically presenting in individuals aged 65–75 years. Its rapid, infiltrative growth explains the subacute (two-month) progression of symptoms. The tumor's location in the left cerebral hemisphere accounts for the focal-onset seizure in the right arm and the contralateral motor weakness (pronator drift). Mass effect and vasogenic edema lead to increased intracranial pressure, causing classic morning headaches and papilledema. Cognitive and personality changes are also common, particularly with frontal or temporal lobe involvement.

E) INCORRECT:

Meningiomas are common, typically benign primary brain tumors that can cause seizures and focal deficits by compressing adjacent brain tissue. However, they are usually very slow-growing, with symptoms often developing over years. This patient's rapid two-month clinical deterioration with significant signs of increased intracranial pressure is inconsistent with the typical natural history of a meningioma.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife 20 minutes after having a seizure. He has had recurrent headaches and dizziness for the past 2 weeks. An MRI of the brain shows multiple, round, well-demarcated lesions in the brain parenchyma at the junction between gray and white matter. This patient's brain lesions are most likely comprised of cells that originate from which of the following organs?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although breast cancers have a tendency to metastasize to the brain, they are not the most common origin of brain metastases. Moreover, cancers of the breast rarely occur in men.

B) INCORRECT:

Colon cancer classically metastasizes hematogenously first to the liver, as venous blood from the colon drains into the portal vein and the hepatic sinusoids, seeding the tumor emboli within the liver parenchyma. Although colon cancers have a tendency to metastasize to the brain, they are not the most common origin of brain metastases.

C) INCORRECT:

Thyroid cancers that spread hematogenously (i.e., follicular thyroid cancer, anaplastic thyroid cancer, and medullary thyroid cancer) predominantly metastasize to the bone and lung but rarely to the brain. Papillary thyroid cancer metastasizes predominantly through lymphatics to the regional lymph nodes; distant metastases from papillary thyroid cancer are uncommon.

D) INCORRECT:

Prostate cancer cells have a high affinity for bone marrow endothelial cells and, therefore, metastasize hematogenously primarily to bone (especially in the lumbosacral spine and pelvis). The prostate is unlikely to be the site of the primary tumor in a patient with brain metastases.

E) INCORRECT:

Renal cell carcinoma most frequently metastasizes to the lungs as the tumor emboli enter the renal vein and inferior vena cava and reach the lungs via the pulmonary artery. Although kidney cancers may rarely metastasize to the brain, they are not the most common origin of brain metastases.

F) CORRECT:

Primary cancers of the lung (particularly small cell lung cancer and adenocarcinoma of the lung) are the most common origin of brain metastases. The 2nd most common origin of brain metastases are cancers of the breast followed by melanoma and cancers of the kidney and colon. Metastatic disease accounts for approx. 50% of all brain tumors.

See “Common origins of cancer metastases” table.
Image Description:

Arrows have been color-coded according to the site of the primary tumor:

Pink: skin cancer
Blue: breast cancer
Green: lung cancer
Orange: pancreatic cancer
Red: colon cancer
Lime: ovarian cancer

The table provides examples of suffixes used to specify the affected organs according to the TNM classification.

G) INCORRECT:

Although melanomas have a tendency to metastasize to the brain, they are not the most common origin of brain metastases.
questions.hint: The junction between the gray and white matter is the typical location for brain metastases, the most common type of intracranial tumors, which visualize as round, well-demarcated intraparenchymal lesions on MRI.

questions.text: A previously healthy 50-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after she was observed having a seizure. On arrival, she is conscious and reports that she feels drowsy. An MRI of the brain shows a 4-cm, round, sharply demarcated mass. She undergoes resection of the mass. A photomicrograph of a section of the resected specimen is shown. This patient's mass is most likely derived from which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neurons very rarely give rise to brain tumors. The vast majority of brain tumors arise from glial cells.

B) INCORRECT:

Hemangioblastomas arise from blood vessels, which are usually located in the infratentorial region. Microscopic examination would show closely arranged, thin-walled capillaries with minimal intervening parenchyma.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a cerebellar tissue specimen (HPS stain; high magnification)

Numerous polygonal neoplastic stromal cells with lipid-laden vacuoles (examples indicated by arrowheads) can be seen, resulting in the typical clear-cell appearance. Additionally, there is an abundance of small, thin-walled blood vessels, many of which are densely packed together (examples indicated by blue overlay).

C) INCORRECT:

Astrocytes give rise to astrocytomas. Glioblastoma multiforme (high-grade astrocytoma) is the most common malignant primary brain tumor in adults and usually occurs after the age of 40. Children are more often affected by low-grade pilocytic astrocytomas. Histopathology would show pleomorphic cells clustered around necrotic areas, forming pseudopalisades.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a cerebral tissue specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)

A high number and density of highly pleomorphic cells with hyperchromatic and irregular nuclei are visible (examples indicated by arrowheads. These cells are aggregated around the periphery of the necrotic zone (green overlay), forming a nuclear pseudopalisading architecture.

These are the characteristic features of glioblastoma multiforme.

D) INCORRECT:

Schwann cells give rise to schwannomas, which occur mostly near the cerebellopontine angle. The most common type is an acoustic neuroma, which arises from the vestibulocochlear nerve. Spindle-shaped cells with mixed hypercellular and hypocellular regions are seen on histopathology.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a biopsy from a peripheral nerve tumor (H&E stain)

Antoni A area (A): area of high cellularity with Verocay bodies. The Verocay bodies consist of rows of pallisading nuclei (green overlay) interspersed with anuclear eosinophilic areas (red overlay).
Antoni B area (B): paucicellular area with unstained myxoid stroma

This is the typical histological appearance of a schwannoma, a benign tumor of the nerve sheath.

E) CORRECT:

Meningiomas arise from arachnoid cells of the arachnoid villi. They are usually benign tumors that manifest as a slow-growing sharply demarcated mass that is composed of spindle-shaped cells arranged in a whorled pattern. The symptoms they cause are due to compression of adjacent structures, e.g., contralateral spastic paresis due to compression of the motor cortex, personality changes due to compression of the frontal lobe, or focal seizures.

The number of psammoma bodies seen in meningiomas depends on the subtype. The psammomatous subtype seen in this patient is characterized by abundant psammoma bodies. Outside of the CNS, psammoma bodies are seen in papillary carcinoma of thyroid, somatostatinoma, mesothelioma, and serous papillary cystadenocarcinoma of ovary and endometrium.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of tissue biopsied from a brain tumor (HPS stain; 400x)

Several eosinophilic cells are visible, arranged in whorls (yellow overlay) and sheets. The nuclei of these cells show features of malignancy (i.e., large size or high N:C ratio, nuclear pleomorphism, prominent nucleoli, and mitotic figures). The intervening stroma contains numerous blood vessels (green overlay).

Hypercellularity, whorled or sheet-like architecture, and hypervascularity are typical features of a meningioma. Psammoma bodies (not seen here) are another characteristic feature of meningioma and would appear as basophilic whorls.

F) INCORRECT:

Oligodendrocytes give rise to oligodendrogliomas, which have cells with clear cytoplasm and a central round nucleus ('fried egg' appearance). They typically arise in the frontal lobe.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of brain tissue (H&E stain; very high magnification)

Monomorphic cells with enlarged, round/oval nuclei surrounded by a clear halo of unstained cytoplasm, which is an artifact of processing, are visible (green overlay). Thin blood vessels with an interlacing pattern are also visible (yellow overlay).

These are the typical features of oligodendroglioma.
questions.hint: The photomicrograph shows whorls of densely packed cells with multiple areas of lamellated calcification that are known as psammoma bodies. This is the typical histopathological appearance of a meningioma.
